<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>

<div id="contentSub2"></div>

<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Largest city in Turkey</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Istanbul_(disambiguation)" title="Istanbul (disambiguation)">Istanbul (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>

<p><b>Istanbul<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8"><a href="#cite_note-8">[b]</a></sup></b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Ë/: secondary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="/Éª/: 'i' in 'kit'">Éª</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span><span title="'t' in 'tie'">t</span><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="'b' in 'buy'">b</span><span title="/Ê/: 'u' in 'push'">Ê</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span></span>/</a></span></span> <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key"><i title="English pronunciation respelling"><span style="font-size:90%">IST</span>-an-<span style="font-size:90%">BUUL</span></i></a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9"><a href="#cite_note-9">[7]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[8]</a></sup> <span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><small><a href="/wiki/American_English" title="American English">US</a> also </small><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/Ë/: primary stress follows">Ë</span><span title="/Éª/: 'i' in 'kit'">Éª</span><span title="'s' in 'sigh'">s</span><span title="'t' in 'tie'">t</span><span title="/Ã¦/: 'a' in 'bad'">Ã¦</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="'b' in 'buy'">b</span><span title="/Ê/: 'u' in 'push'">Ê</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span></span>/</a></span></span> <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key"><i title="English pronunciation respelling"><span style="font-size:90%">IST</span>-an-buul</i></a>; <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">Turkish</a>: <i lang="tr">Ä°stanbul</i> <small></small><span class="IPA" lang="tr-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Turkish" title="Help:IPA/Turkish">[isËtanbuÉ«]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_pronunciation.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fa/Istanbul_pronunciation.ogg" title="Istanbul pronunciation.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>), formerly known as Constantinople, is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_cities_and_towns_in_Turkey" title="List of largest cities and towns in Turkey">largest city</a> in <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">The Republic of Turkey</a>, serving as the country's economic, cultural and historic hub. The city straddles the <a href="/wiki/Bosporus" title="Bosporus">Bosporus</a> <a href="/wiki/Strait" title="Strait">strait</a>, lying in both <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>, and has a population of over 15 million residents, comprising 19% of the population of Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Population_of_Turkey_5-1"><a href="#cite_note-Population_of_Turkey-5">[4]</a></sup> Istanbul is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_cities_by_population_within_city_limits" title="List of European cities by population within city limits">most populous European city</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a href="#cite_note-11">[c]</a></sup> and the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_cities" title="List of largest cities">15th-largest city</a>.
</p><p>The city was founded as <a href="/wiki/Byzantium" title="Byzantium">Byzantium</a> (<i>Byzantion</i>) in the 7th century BCE by <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Greek</a> settlers from <a href="/wiki/Megara" title="Megara">Megara</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herrin2009_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-Herrin2009-12">[9]</a></sup> In 330 CE, the <a href="/wiki/Roman_emperor" title="Roman emperor">Roman emperor</a> <a href="/wiki/Constantine_the_Great" title="Constantine the Great">Constantine the Great</a> made it his imperial capital, renaming it first as <a href="/wiki/New_Rome" title="New Rome">New Rome</a> (<i>Nova Roma</i>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica-Istanbul_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-Istanbul-13">[10]</a></sup> and then as <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a> (<i>Constantinopolis</i>) after himself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica-Istanbul_13-1"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-Istanbul-13">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ODB_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-ODB-14">[11]</a></sup> The city grew in size and influence, eventually becoming a beacon of the <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road" title="Silk Road">Silk Road</a> and one of the most important cities in history. 
</p><p>The city served as an imperial capital for almost 1600 years: during the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman</a>/<a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine</a> (330â1204), <a href="/wiki/Latin_Empire" title="Latin Empire">Latin</a> (1204â1261), <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire_under_the_Palaiologos_dynasty" title="Byzantine Empire under the Palaiologos dynasty">late Byzantine</a> (1261â1453), and <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman</a> (1453â1922) empires.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEÃelik1993xv_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEÃelik1993xv-15">[12]</a></sup> The city played a key role in the advancement of <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> during Roman/Byzantine times, hosting four (including <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Chalcedon" title="Council of Chalcedon">Chalcedon</a> (<a href="/wiki/Kad%C4%B1k%C3%B6y" title="KadÄ±kÃ¶y">KadÄ±kÃ¶y</a>) on the Asian side) of the <a href="/wiki/First_seven_ecumenical_councils" title="First seven ecumenical councils">first seven ecumenical councils</a> (all of which were in present-day Turkey) before its transformation to an <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islamic</a> stronghold following the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">Fall of Constantinople</a> in 1453 CEâespecially after becoming the seat of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Caliphate" title="Ottoman Caliphate">Ottoman Caliphate</a> in 1517.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-maag1145_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-maag1145-16">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1923, after the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_War_of_Independence" title="Turkish War of Independence">Turkish War of Independence</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">Ankara</a> replaced the city as the capital of the newly formed <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Republic of Turkey</a>. In 1930, the city's name was officially changed to Istanbul, the Turkish rendering of <i>Îµá¼°Ï Ïá½´Î½ Î ÏÎ»Î¹Î½ (<small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Greek" title="Romanization of Greek">romanized</a>:</small> eis tá¸n PÃ³lin; to the City)</i>, the appellation <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a> speakers used since the eleventh century to colloquially refer to the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica-Istanbul_13-2"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-Istanbul-13">[10]</a></sup>
</p><p>Over <span class="nowrap">13.4 million</span> foreign visitors came to Istanbul in 2018, eight years after it was named a <a href="/wiki/European_Capital_of_Culture" title="European Capital of Culture">European Capital of Culture</a>, making it the world's eighth most visited city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-statista.com_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-statista.com-17">[14]</a></sup> Istanbul is home to several <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Sites</a>, and hosts the headquarters of numerous Turkish companies, accounting for more than thirty percent of the country's <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Turkey" title="Economy of Turkey">economy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hisdic_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-hisdic-18">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecd_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-oecd-19">[16]</a></sup>
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Toponymy">Toponymy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Istanbul" title="Names of Istanbul">Names of Istanbul</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Column_of_Constantine_2.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5184" data-file-width="3456" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Column_of_Constantine_2.JPG/170px-Column_of_Constantine_2.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Column_of_Constantine_2.JPG/255px-Column_of_Constantine_2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Column_of_Constantine_2.JPG/340px-Column_of_Constantine_2.JPG 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Column_of_Constantine_2.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Column_of_Constantine" title="Column of Constantine">Column of Constantine</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forum_of_Constantine_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-Forum_of_Constantine-20">[17]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The first known name of the city is <i><a href="/wiki/Byzantium" title="Byzantium">Byzantium</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a>: <span lang="el">ÎÏÎ¶Î¬Î½ÏÎ¹Î¿Î½</span>, <i>ByzÃ¡ntion</i>), the name given to it at its foundation by <a href="/wiki/Megara" title="Megara">Megarian</a> colonists around 657 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica-Istanbul_13-3"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-Istanbul-13">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-roo177_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-roo177-21">[18]</a></sup> Megarian colonists claimed a direct line back to the founders of the city, Byzas, the son of the god Poseidon and the nymph CeroÃ«ssa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-roo177_21-1"><a href="#cite_note-roo177-21">[18]</a></sup> Modern excavations have raised the possibility that the name Byzantium might reflect the sites of native Thracian settlements that preceded the fully fledged town.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGeorgacas1947352ff_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGeorgacas1947352ff-22">[19]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a> comes from the Latin name Constantinus, after <a href="/wiki/Constantine_the_Great" title="Constantine the Great">Constantine the Great</a>, the Roman emperor who refounded the city in 324 CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-roo177_21-2"><a href="#cite_note-roo177-21">[18]</a></sup> Constantinople remained the most common name for the city in the West until the 1930s, when Turkish authorities began to press for the use of "Istanbul" in foreign languages. <i>á¸²osá¹­aná¹­Ä«nÄ«ye</i> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman_Turkish_language" title="Ottoman Turkish language">Ottoman Turkish</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ota">ÙØ³Ø·ÙØ·ÙÙÙÙ</span>) and <i>Ä°stanbul</i> were the names used alternatively by the Ottomans during their rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENecipoÄlu2010262_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENecipoÄlu2010262-23">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p>The name <i>Ä°stanbul</i> (<small>Turkish pronunciation:Â </small><span class="IPA" lang="tr-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Turkish" title="Help:IPA/Turkish">[isËtanbuÉ«]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_pronunciation.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fa/Istanbul_pronunciation.ogg" title="Istanbul pronunciation.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>, <small>colloquially</small> <small>Turkish pronunciation:Â </small><span class="IPA" lang="tr-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Turkish" title="Help:IPA/Turkish">[É¯sËtambuÉ«]</a></span>) is commonly held to derive from the <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Greek" title="Medieval Greek">Medieval Greek</a> phrase <span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><span lang="grc">"Îµá¼°Ï Ïá½´Î½ <a href="/wiki/Polis" title="Polis">Î ÏÎ»Î¹Î½</a>"</span></span> (pronounced <small>Greek pronunciation:Â </small><span class="IPA" lang="el-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Greek" title="Help:IPA/Greek">[is tim Ëbolin]</a></span>), which means "to the city"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[21]</a></sup> and is how Constantinople was referred to by the local Greeks. This reflected its status as the only major city in the vicinity. The importance of Constantinople in the Ottoman world was also reflected by its Ottoman nickname <i>Der Saadet</i> meaning the "Gate to Prosperity" in Ottoman Turkish.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[22]</a></sup> An alternative view is that the name evolved directly from the name <i>Constantinople</i>, with the first and third syllables dropped.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-roo177_21-3"><a href="#cite_note-roo177-21">[18]</a></sup> Some Ottoman sources of the 17th century, such as <a href="/wiki/Evliya_%C3%87elebi" title="Evliya Ãelebi">Evliya Ãelebi</a>, describe it as the common Turkish name of the time; between the late 17th and late 18th centuries, it was also in official use. The first use of the word <i>Islambol</i> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman_Turkish_language" title="Ottoman Turkish language">Ottoman Turkish</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ota">Ø§Ø³ÙØ§ÙØ¨ÙÙ</span>) on coinage was in 1730 during the reign of Sultan <a href="/wiki/Mahmud_I" title="Mahmud I">Mahmud I</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFinkel200557,_383_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFinkel200557,_383-26">[23]</a></sup> In modern <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">Turkish</a>, the name is written as <i>Ä°stanbul</i>, with a dotted Ä°, as the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_alphabet" title="Turkish alphabet">Turkish alphabet</a> distinguishes between a <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0" title="Ä°">dotted</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dotless_I" title="Dotless I">dotless I</a>. In English the stress is on the first or last syllable, but in Turkish it is on the second syllable (<i>tan</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGÃ¶kselKerslake200527_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGÃ¶kselKerslake200527-27">[24]</a></sup> A person from the city is an <i>Ä°stanbullu</i> (plural: <i>Ä°stanbullular</i>); <i>Istanbulite</i> is used in English.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKeyder199995_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKeyder199995-28">[25]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Istanbul" title="History of Istanbul">History of Istanbul</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Istanbul_history" title="Timeline of Istanbul history">Timeline of Istanbul history</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Keystone_Constantine_Forum_Istanbul.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Keystone_Constantine_Forum_Istanbul.JPG/220px-Keystone_Constantine_Forum_Istanbul.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Keystone_Constantine_Forum_Istanbul.JPG/330px-Keystone_Constantine_Forum_Istanbul.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Keystone_Constantine_Forum_Istanbul.JPG/440px-Keystone_Constantine_Forum_Istanbul.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Keystone_Constantine_Forum_Istanbul.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>This large keystone might have belonged to a <a href="/wiki/Triumphal_arch" title="Triumphal arch">triumphal arch</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Forum_of_Constantine" title="Forum of Constantine">Forum of Constantine</a> (present-day <a href="/wiki/%C3%87emberlita%C5%9F,_Fatih" title="ÃemberlitaÅ, Fatih">ÃemberlitaÅ</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forum_of_Constantine_20-1"><a href="#cite_note-Forum_of_Constantine-20">[17]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> artifacts, uncovered by archeologists at the beginning of the 21st century, indicate that Istanbul's historic peninsula was settled as far back as the 6th millennium BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC-Rainsford-2009_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-Rainsford-2009-29">[26]</a></sup> That early settlement, important in the spread of the <a href="/wiki/Neolithic_Revolution" title="Neolithic Revolution">Neolithic Revolution</a> from the Near East to Europe, lasted for almost a millennium before being inundated by rising water levels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[27]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC-Rainsford-2009_29-1"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-Rainsford-2009-29">[26]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[29]</a></sup> The first human settlement on the Asian side, the Fikirtepe mound, is from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Copper_Age" title="Copper Age">Copper Age</a> period, with artifacts dating from 5500 to 3500 BCE,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[30]</a></sup> On the European side, near the point of the peninsula (<a href="/wiki/Sarayburnu" title="Sarayburnu">Sarayburnu</a>), there was a Thracian settlement during the early 1st millennium BCE. Modern authors have linked it to the Thracian toponym <i>Lygos</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-janin_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-janin-34">[31]</a></sup> mentioned by <a href="/wiki/Pliny_the_Elder" title="Pliny the Elder">Pliny the Elder</a> as an earlier name for the site of Byzantium.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[32]</a></sup>
</p><p>The history of the city proper begins around 660 BCE,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britannica-Istanbul_13-4"><a href="#cite_note-Britannica-Istanbul-13">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBloomBlair20091_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBloomBlair20091-36">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-byz-date_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-byz-date-42">[d]</a></sup> when Greek settlers from Megara established Byzantium on the European side of the Bosphorus. The settlers built an <a href="/wiki/Acropolis" title="Acropolis">acropolis</a> adjacent to the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horn" title="Golden Horn">Golden Horn</a> on the site of the early Thracian settlements, fueling the nascent city's economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEÃelik199311_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEÃelik199311-43">[39]</a></sup> The city experienced a brief period of <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Persian</a> rule at the turn of the 5th century BCE, but the Greeks recaptured it during the <a href="/wiki/Greco-Persian_Wars" title="Greco-Persian Wars">Greco-Persian Wars</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDe_Souza200388_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDe_Souza200388-44">[40]</a></sup> Byzantium then continued as part of the <a href="/wiki/Delian_League" title="Delian League">Athenian League</a> and its successor, the <a href="/wiki/Second_Athenian_League" title="Second Athenian League">Second Athenian League</a>, before gaining independence in 355 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFreely199620_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFreely199620-45">[41]</a></sup> Long allied with the Romans, Byzantium officially became a part of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> in 73 CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFreely199622_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFreely199622-46">[42]</a></sup> Byzantium's decision to side with the <a href="/wiki/Roman_usurper" title="Roman usurper">Roman usurper</a> <a href="/wiki/Pescennius_Niger" title="Pescennius Niger">Pescennius Niger</a> against Emperor <a href="/wiki/Septimius_Severus" title="Septimius Severus">Septimius Severus</a> cost it dearly; by the time it surrendered at the end of 195 CE, two years of siege had left the city devastated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrant19968â10_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrant19968â10-47">[43]</a></sup> Five years later, Severus began to rebuild Byzantium, and the city regainedâand, by some accounts, surpassedâits previous prosperity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELimberis199411â12_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELimberis199411â12-48">[44]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rise_and_fall_of_Constantinople_and_the_Byzantine_Empire">Rise and fall of Constantinople and the Byzantine Empire</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:234px;max-width:234px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:232px;max-width:232px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_Hagia_Irene_IMG_8067_1920.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2756" decoding="async" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Istanbul_Hagia_Irene_IMG_8067_1920.jpg/230px-Istanbul_Hagia_Irene_IMG_8067_1920.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Istanbul_Hagia_Irene_IMG_8067_1920.jpg/345px-Istanbul_Hagia_Irene_IMG_8067_1920.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Istanbul_Hagia_Irene_IMG_8067_1920.jpg/460px-Istanbul_Hagia_Irene_IMG_8067_1920.jpg 2x" width="230"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Originally built by <a href="/wiki/Constantine_the_Great" title="Constantine the Great">Constantine the Great</a> in the 4th century and later rebuilt by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Justinian_the_Great" title="Justinian the Great">Justinian the Great</a> after the <a href="/wiki/Nika_riots" title="Nika riots">Nika riots</a> in 532, the <a href="/wiki/Hagia_Irene" title="Hagia Irene">Hagia Irene</a> is an <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a> located in the outer courtyard of <a href="/wiki/Topkap%C4%B1_Palace" title="TopkapÄ± Palace">TopkapÄ± Palace</a> in Istanbul. It is one of the few <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine</a> era churches that were never converted into mosques; during the Ottoman period it served as TopkapÄ±'s principal <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Armoury" title="Armoury">armoury</a>.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:232px;max-width:232px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_(2216460729).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2534" data-file-width="3329" decoding="async" height="175" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg/230px-Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg/345px-Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg/460px-Turkey-3019_-_Hagia_Sophia_%282216460729%29.jpg 2x" width="230"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Originally a church, later a mosque, the 6th-century <a href="/wiki/Hagia_Sophia" title="Hagia Sophia">Hagia Sophia</a> (532â537) by <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine</a> emperor <a href="/wiki/Justinian_I" title="Justinian I">Justinian the Great</a> was the largest cathedral in the world for nearly a thousand years, until the completion of the <a href="/wiki/Seville_Cathedral" title="Seville Cathedral">Seville Cathedral</a> (1507) in <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a>.</div></div></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bozdo%C4%A3an_Kemeri_-_panoramio.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2612" data-file-width="3908" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Bozdo%C4%A3an_Kemeri_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-Bozdo%C4%A3an_Kemeri_-_panoramio.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Bozdo%C4%A3an_Kemeri_-_panoramio.jpg/330px-Bozdo%C4%A3an_Kemeri_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Bozdo%C4%A3an_Kemeri_-_panoramio.jpg/440px-Bozdo%C4%A3an_Kemeri_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bozdo%C4%A3an_Kemeri_-_panoramio.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The construction of the <a href="/wiki/Aqueduct_of_Valens" title="Aqueduct of Valens">Aqueduct of Valens</a> began during the reign of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman</a> emperor <a href="/wiki/Constantius_II" title="Constantius II">Constantius II</a> and was completed in 373 during the reign of emperor <a href="/wiki/Valens" title="Valens">Valens</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Constantine the Great effectively became the emperor of the whole of the Roman Empire in September 324.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[45]</a></sup> Two months later, he laid out the plans for a new, Christian city to replace Byzantium. As the eastern capital of the empire, the city was named <i><a href="/wiki/New_Rome" title="New Rome">Nova Roma</a></i>; most called it Constantinople, a name that persisted into the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[46]</a></sup> On 11 May 330, Constantinople was proclaimed the capital of the Roman Empire, which was later permanently divided between the two sons of <a href="/wiki/Theodosius_I" title="Theodosius I">Theodosius I</a> upon his death on 17 January 395, when the city became the capital of the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Eastern Roman (Byzantine) Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ba222_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-ba222-51">[47]</a></sup>
</p><p>The establishment of Constantinople was one of Constantine's most lasting accomplishments, shifting Roman power eastward as the city became a center of Greek culture and Christianity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ba222_51-1"><a href="#cite_note-ba222-51">[47]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gr63_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-gr63-52">[48]</a></sup> Numerous churches were built across the city, including <a href="/wiki/Hagia_Sophia" title="Hagia Sophia">Hagia Sophia</a> which was built during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Justinian_I" title="Justinian I">Justinian the Great</a> and remained the world's largest cathedral for a thousand years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-klwa171_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-klwa171-53">[49]</a></sup> Constantine also undertook a major renovation and expansion of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hippodrome_of_Constantinople" title="Hippodrome of Constantinople">Hippodrome of Constantinople</a>; accommodating tens of thousands of spectators, the hippodrome became central to civic life and, in the 5th and 6th centuries, the center of episodes of unrest, including the <a href="/wiki/Nika_riots" title="Nika riots">Nika riots</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[50]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[51]</a></sup> Constantinople's location also ensured its existence would stand the test of time; for many centuries, its walls and seafront protected Europe against invaders from the east and the advance of Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gr63_52-1"><a href="#cite_note-gr63-52">[48]</a></sup> During most of the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>, the latter part of the Byzantine era, Constantinople was the largest and wealthiest city on the European continent and at times the largest in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[53]</a></sup> Constantinople is generally considered to be the center and the "cradle of Orthodox <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_civilization" title="Christian civilization">Christian civilization</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[54]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[55]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Matrak%C3%A7%C4%B1_Nasuh_-_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2098" data-file-width="1454" decoding="async" height="245" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Matrak%C3%A7%C4%B1_Nasuh_-_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg/170px-Matrak%C3%A7%C4%B1_Nasuh_-_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Matrak%C3%A7%C4%B1_Nasuh_-_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg/255px-Matrak%C3%A7%C4%B1_Nasuh_-_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Matrak%C3%A7%C4%B1_Nasuh_-_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg/340px-Matrak%C3%A7%C4%B1_Nasuh_-_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Matrak%C3%A7%C4%B1_Nasuh_-_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of Istanbul in the 16th century by <a href="/wiki/Matrak%C3%A7%C4%B1_Nasuh" title="MatrakÃ§Ä± Nasuh">MatrakÃ§Ä± Nasuh</a></div></div></div>
<p>Constantinople began to decline continuously after the end of the reign of <a href="/wiki/Basil_II" title="Basil II">Basil II</a> in 1025. The <a href="/wiki/Fourth_Crusade" title="Fourth Crusade">Fourth Crusade</a> was diverted from its purpose in 1204, and the city was sacked and pillaged by the crusaders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGregory2010324â29_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGregory2010324â29-60">[56]</a></sup> They established the <a href="/wiki/Latin_Empire" title="Latin Empire">Latin Empire</a> in place of the Orthodox Byzantine Empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGregory2010330â333_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGregory2010330â333-61">[57]</a></sup> Hagia Sophia was converted to a Catholic church in 1204. The Byzantine Empire was restored, albeit weakened, in 1261.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGregory2010340_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGregory2010340-62">[58]</a></sup> Constantinople's churches, defenses, and basic services were in disrepair,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGregory2010341â342_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGregory2010341â342-63">[59]</a></sup> and its population had dwindled to a hundred thousand from half a million during the 8th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pop-figures_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-pop-figures-64">[e]</a></sup> After the reconquest of 1261, however, some of the city's monuments were restored, and some, like the two <a href="/wiki/Deesis" title="Deesis">Deesis</a> mosaics in Hagia Sophia and Kariye, were created.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[60]</a></sup>
</p><p>Various economic and military policies instituted by <a href="/wiki/Andronikos_II_Palaiologos" title="Andronikos II Palaiologos">Andronikos II</a>, such as the reduction of military forces, weakened the empire and left it vulnerable to attack.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEReinert2002258â260_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReinert2002258â260-66">[61]</a></sup> In the mid-14th-century, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Turks" title="Ottoman Turks">Ottoman Turks</a> began a strategy of gradually taking smaller towns and cities, cutting off Constantinople's supply routes and strangling it slowly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBaynes194947_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaynes194947-67">[62]</a></sup> On 29 May 1453, after an eight-week siege (during which the last Roman emperor, <a href="/wiki/Constantine_XI_Palaiologos" title="Constantine XI Palaiologos">Constantine XI</a>, was killed), <a href="/wiki/Sultan" title="Sultan">Sultan</a> <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_II" title="Mehmed II">Mehmed II</a> "the Conqueror" <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">captured Constantinople</a> and declared it the new capital of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>. Hours later, the sultan rode to the Hagia Sophia and summoned an imam to proclaim the <a href="/wiki/Shahada" title="Shahada">Islamic creed</a>, converting the grand cathedral into an imperial mosque due to the city's refusal to surrender peacefully.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGregory2010394â399_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGregory2010394â399-68">[63]</a></sup> Mehmed declared himself as the new <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kayser-i_R%C3%BBm" title="Kayser-i RÃ»m">Kayser-i RÃ»m</a></i> (the Ottoman Turkish equivalent of the <a href="/wiki/Caesar_(title)" title="Caesar (title)">Caesar</a> of Rome) and the Ottoman state was reorganized into an empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBÃ©har199938_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBÃ©har199938-69">[64]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBideleuxJeffries199871_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBideleuxJeffries199871-70">[65]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ottoman_Empire_and_Turkish_Republic_eras">Ottoman Empire and Turkish Republic eras</span></h3>
<p>Following the conquest of Constantinople,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Stamboul_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-Stamboul-72">[f]</a></sup> Mehmed II immediately set out to revitalize the city. Cognizant that revitalization would fail without the repopulation of the city, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mehmed_the_Conqueror" title="Mehmed the Conqueror">Mehmed II</a> welcomed everyoneâforeigners, criminals, and runawaysâ showing extraordinary openness and willingness to incorporate outsiders that came to define Ottoman political culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[67]</a></sup> He also invited people from all over <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> to his capital, creating a cosmopolitan society that persisted through much of the Ottoman period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[68]</a></sup> Revitalizing Istanbul also required a massive program of restorations, of everything from roads to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Valens_Aqueduct#Ottoman_period" title="Valens Aqueduct">aqueducts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hughes2020_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-hughes2020-75">[69]</a></sup> Like many monarchs before and since, Mehmed II transformed Istanbul's urban landscape with wholesale redevelopment of the city center.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-madden2020_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-madden2020-76">[70]</a></sup> There was a <a href="/wiki/Topkap%C4%B1_Palace" title="TopkapÄ± Palace">huge new palace</a> to rival, if not overshadow, <a href="/wiki/Great_Palace_of_Constantinople" title="Great Palace of Constantinople">the old one</a>, a new covered market (still standing as the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Bazaar,_Istanbul" title="Grand Bazaar, Istanbul">Grand Bazaar</a>), porticoes, pavilions, walkways, as well as more than a dozen new mosques.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hughes2020_75-1"><a href="#cite_note-hughes2020-75">[69]</a></sup> Mehmed II turned the ramshackle old town into something that looked like an imperial capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-madden2020_76-1"><a href="#cite_note-madden2020-76">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Social_stratification" title="Social stratification">Social hierarchy</a> was ignored by the rampant plague, which killed the rich and the poor alike in the 16th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-blackd_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-blackd-77">[71]</a></sup> Money could not protect the rich from all the discomforts and harsher sides of Istanbul.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-blackd_77-1"><a href="#cite_note-blackd-77">[71]</a></sup> Although <a href="/wiki/List_of_sultans_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="List of sultans of the Ottoman Empire">the Sultan</a> lived at a safe remove from the masses, and the wealthy and poor tended to live side by side, for the most part Istanbul was not <a href="/wiki/Zoning" title="Zoning">zoned</a> as modern cities are.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-blackd_77-2"><a href="#cite_note-blackd-77">[71]</a></sup> Opulent houses shared the same streets and districts with tiny hovels.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-blackd_77-3"><a href="#cite_note-blackd-77">[71]</a></sup> Those rich enough to have secluded country properties had a chance of escaping the periodic <a href="/wiki/Epidemic" title="Epidemic">epidemics</a> of sickness that blighted Istanbul.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-blackd_77-4"><a href="#cite_note-blackd-77">[71]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_panorama_(16293921746).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4162" data-file-width="7461" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Istanbul_panorama_%2816293921746%29.jpg/300px-Istanbul_panorama_%2816293921746%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Istanbul_panorama_%2816293921746%29.jpg/450px-Istanbul_panorama_%2816293921746%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Istanbul_panorama_%2816293921746%29.jpg/600px-Istanbul_panorama_%2816293921746%29.jpg 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_panorama_(16293921746).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>View of the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horn" title="Golden Horn">Golden Horn</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seraglio_Point" title="Seraglio Point">Seraglio Point</a> from <a href="/wiki/Galata_Tower" title="Galata Tower">Galata Tower</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman_Dynasty" title="Ottoman Dynasty">Ottoman Dynasty</a> claimed the status of <a href="/wiki/Caliphate" title="Caliphate">caliphate</a> in 1517, with Constantinople remaining the capital of this <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Caliphate" title="Ottoman Caliphate">last caliphate</a> for four centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-maag1145_16-1"><a href="#cite_note-maag1145-16">[13]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Suleiman_the_Magnificent" title="Suleiman the Magnificent">Suleiman the Magnificent</a>'s reign from 1520 to 1566 was a period of especially great artistic and architectural achievement; chief architect <a href="/wiki/Mimar_Sinan" title="Mimar Sinan">Mimar Sinan</a> designed several iconic buildings in the city, while Ottoman arts of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%B0znik_pottery" title="Ä°znik pottery">ceramics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stained_glass" title="Stained glass">stained glass</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_calligraphy" title="Islamic calligraphy">calligraphy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_miniature" title="Ottoman miniature">miniature</a> flourished.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[72]</a></sup> The population of Constantinople was 570,000 by the end of the 18th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chfo_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-chfo-79">[73]</a></sup>
</p><p>A period of rebellion at the start of the 19th century led to the rise of the progressive Sultan <a href="/wiki/Mahmud_II" title="Mahmud II">Mahmud II</a> and eventually to the <i><a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">Tanzimat</a></i> period, which produced political reforms and allowed new technology to be introduced to the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[74]</a></sup> Bridges across the Golden Horn were constructed during this period,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[75]</a></sup> and Constantinople was connected to the rest of the European railway network in the 1880s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ha251_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-ha251-82">[76]</a></sup> Modern facilities, such as a water supply network, electricity, telephones, and trams, were gradually introduced to Constantinople over the following decades, although later than to other European cities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[77]</a></sup> The modernization efforts were not enough to forestall the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Decline_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Decline of the Ottoman Empire">decline of the Ottoman Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[78]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:358px;max-width:358px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:177px;max-width:177px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aerial_view_of_Istanbul_19_March_1918.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="865" data-file-width="1271" decoding="async" height="119" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Aerial_view_of_Istanbul_19_March_1918.jpg/175px-Aerial_view_of_Istanbul_19_March_1918.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Aerial_view_of_Istanbul_19_March_1918.jpg/263px-Aerial_view_of_Istanbul_19_March_1918.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/Aerial_view_of_Istanbul_19_March_1918.jpg/350px-Aerial_view_of_Istanbul_19_March_1918.jpg 2x" width="175"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:177px;max-width:177px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aerial_view_of_Istanbul_on_19_March_1918.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="869" data-file-width="1273" decoding="async" height="119" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Aerial_view_of_Istanbul_on_19_March_1918.jpg/175px-Aerial_view_of_Istanbul_on_19_March_1918.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Aerial_view_of_Istanbul_on_19_March_1918.jpg/263px-Aerial_view_of_Istanbul_on_19_March_1918.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Aerial_view_of_Istanbul_on_19_March_1918.jpg/350px-Aerial_view_of_Istanbul_on_19_March_1918.jpg 2x" width="175"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">Two aerial photos showing the Golden Horn and the Bosphorus, taken from a German zeppelin on 19 March 1918</div></div></div></div>
<p>Sultan <a href="/wiki/Abdul_Hamid_II" title="Abdul Hamid II">Abdul Hamid II</a> was deposed with the <a href="/wiki/Young_Turk_Revolution" title="Young Turk Revolution">Young Turk Revolution</a> in 1908 and the <a href="/wiki/General_Assembly_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="General Assembly of the Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Parliament</a>, closed since <a href="/wiki/First_Constitutional_Era" title="First Constitutional Era">14 February 1878</a>, was reopened 30 years later on 23 July 1908, which marked the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Second_Constitutional_Era" title="Second Constitutional Era">Second Constitutional Era</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tarihiolaylar_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-tarihiolaylar-85">[79]</a></sup> A series of wars in the early 20th century, such as the <a href="/wiki/Italo-Turkish_War" title="Italo-Turkish War">Italo-Turkish War</a> (1911â1912) and the <a href="/wiki/Balkan_Wars" title="Balkan Wars">Balkan Wars</a> (1912â1913), plagued the ailing empire's capital and resulted in the <a href="/wiki/1913_Ottoman_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1913 Ottoman coup d'Ã©tat">1913 Ottoman coup d'Ã©tat</a>, which brought the regime of the <a href="/wiki/Three_Pashas" title="Three Pashas">Three Pashas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[80]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bankalar_Caddesi_in_the_1920%27s.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="977" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="269" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Bankalar_Caddesi_in_the_1920%27s.jpg/220px-Bankalar_Caddesi_in_the_1920%27s.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Bankalar_Caddesi_in_the_1920%27s.jpg/330px-Bankalar_Caddesi_in_the_1920%27s.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Bankalar_Caddesi_in_the_1920%27s.jpg/440px-Bankalar_Caddesi_in_the_1920%27s.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bankalar_Caddesi_in_the_1920%27s.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A view of <a href="/wiki/Bankalar_Caddesi" title="Bankalar Caddesi">Bankalar Caddesi</a> (<i>Banks Street</i>) in the <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="History of the Republic of Turkey">late 1920s</a>. Completed in 1892, the Ottoman Central Bank headquarters is seen at left. In 1995 the <a href="/wiki/Borsa_Istanbul" title="Borsa Istanbul">Istanbul Stock Exchange</a> moved to <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0stinye" title="Ä°stinye">Ä°stinye</a>, while numerous Turkish banks have moved to <a href="/wiki/Levent" title="Levent">Levent</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maslak" title="Maslak">Maslak</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[81]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The Ottoman Empire joined <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> (1914â1918) on the side of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a> and was ultimately defeated. The <a href="/wiki/Deportation_of_Armenian_intellectuals_on_24_April_1915" title="Deportation of Armenian intellectuals on 24 April 1915">deportation of Armenian intellectuals on 24 April 1915</a> was among the major events which marked the start of the <a href="/wiki/Armenian_genocide" title="Armenian genocide">Armenian genocide</a> during WWI.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[82]</a></sup> Due to Ottoman and Turkish policies of <a href="/wiki/Turkification" title="Turkification">Turkification</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_cleansing" title="Ethnic cleansing">ethnic cleansing</a>, the city's <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Christianity in the Ottoman Empire">Christian</a> population declined from 450,000 to 240,000 between 1914 and 1927.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[83]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Armistice_of_Mudros" title="Armistice of Mudros">Armistice of Mudros</a> was signed on 30 October 1918 and the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allies</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Occupation_of_Constantinople" title="Occupation of Constantinople">occupied Constantinople</a> on 13 November 1918. The Ottoman Parliament was dissolved by the Allies on 11 April 1920 and the Ottoman delegation led by <a href="/wiki/Damat_Ferid_Pasha" title="Damat Ferid Pasha">Damat Ferid Pasha</a> was forced to sign the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres" title="Treaty of SÃ¨vres">Treaty of SÃ¨vres</a> on 10 August 1920.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Following the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_War_of_Independence" title="Turkish War of Independence">Turkish War of Independence</a> (1919â1922), the <a href="/wiki/Grand_National_Assembly_of_Turkey" title="Grand National Assembly of Turkey">Grand National Assembly of Turkey</a> in <a href="/wiki/Ankara" title="Ankara">Ankara</a> abolished the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sultanate" title="Sultanate">Sultanate</a> on 1 November 1922, and the last Ottoman Sultan, <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_VI" title="Mehmed VI">Mehmed VI</a>, was declared <i><a href="/wiki/150_personae_non_gratae_of_Turkey" title="150 personae non gratae of Turkey">persona non grata</a></i>. Leaving aboard the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">British</a> <a href="/wiki/Warship" title="Warship">warship</a> <a href="/wiki/HMS_Malaya" title="HMS Malaya">HMS <i>Malaya</i></a> on 17 November 1922, he went into exile and died in <a href="/wiki/Sanremo" title="Sanremo">Sanremo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a>, on 16 May 1926. The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lausanne" title="Treaty of Lausanne">Treaty of Lausanne</a> was signed on 24 July 1923, and the occupation of Constantinople ended with the departure of the last forces of the Allies from the city on 4 October 1923.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-liberation-of-istanbul_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-liberation-of-istanbul-90">[84]</a></sup> Turkish forces of the Ankara government, commanded by <a href="/wiki/%C5%9E%C3%BCkr%C3%BC_Naili_G%C3%B6kberk" title="ÅÃ¼krÃ¼ Naili GÃ¶kberk">ÅÃ¼krÃ¼ Naili Pasha</a> (3rd Corps), entered the city with a ceremony on 6 October 1923, which has been marked as the <i>Liberation Day</i> of Istanbul (<a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">Turkish</a>: <i>Ä°stanbul'un KurtuluÅu</i>) and is commemorated every year on its anniversary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-liberation-of-istanbul_90-1"><a href="#cite_note-liberation-of-istanbul-90">[84]</a></sup> On 29 October 1923 the Grand National Assembly of Turkey declared the establishment of the Turkish Republic, with Ankara as its capital. <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk">Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk</a> became the Republic's first <a href="/wiki/President_of_Turkey" title="President of Turkey">President</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[85]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>A <a href="/wiki/Varl%C4%B1k_Vergisi" title="VarlÄ±k Vergisi">1942 wealth tax</a> assessed mainly on non-Muslims led to the transfer or liquidation of many businesses owned by religious minorities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[87]</a></sup> From the late 1940s and early 1950s, Istanbul underwent great structural change, as new public squares, boulevards, and avenues were constructed throughout the city, sometimes at the expense of historical buildings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[88]</a></sup> The population of Istanbul began to rapidly increase in the 1970s, as people from Anatolia migrated to the city to find employment in the many new factories that were built on the outskirts of the sprawling metropolis. This sudden, sharp rise in the city's population caused a large demand for housing, and many previously outlying villages and forests became engulfed into the <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_area" title="Metropolitan area">metropolitan area</a> of Istanbul.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[89]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Turkey" title="Geography of Turkey">Geography of Turkey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Geology_of_Turkey" title="Geology of Turkey">Geology of Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_by_Sentinel-2,_2020-05-09.jpg"><img alt="Satellite image showing a thin piece of land, densely populated on the south, bisected by a waterway" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="7020" data-file-width="7668" decoding="async" height="201" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Istanbul_by_Sentinel-2%2C_2020-05-09.jpg/220px-Istanbul_by_Sentinel-2%2C_2020-05-09.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Istanbul_by_Sentinel-2%2C_2020-05-09.jpg/330px-Istanbul_by_Sentinel-2%2C_2020-05-09.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Istanbul_by_Sentinel-2%2C_2020-05-09.jpg/440px-Istanbul_by_Sentinel-2%2C_2020-05-09.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_by_Sentinel-2,_2020-05-09.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Satellite view of Istanbul and the <a href="/wiki/Strait" title="Strait">strait</a> of <a href="/wiki/Bosporus" title="Bosporus">Bosporus</a></div></div></div>
<p>Istanbul is located in north-western <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a> and straddles the straitÂ Bosporus, which provides the only passage from the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean</a> via the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Marmara" title="Sea of Marmara">Sea of Marmara</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hisdic_18-1"><a href="#cite_note-hisdic-18">[15]</a></sup> Historically, the city has been ideally situated for trade and defense: The confluence of the Sea of Marmara, the Bosphorus, and the Golden Horn provide both ideal defense against enemy attack and a natural toll-gate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hisdic_18-2"><a href="#cite_note-hisdic-18">[15]</a></sup> Several picturesque islandsâ<a href="/wiki/B%C3%BCy%C3%BCkada" title="BÃ¼yÃ¼kada">BÃ¼yÃ¼kada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Heybeliada" title="Heybeliada">Heybeliada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Burgazada" title="Burgazada">Burgazada</a>, <a href="/wiki/K%C4%B1nal%C4%B1ada" title="KÄ±nalÄ±ada">KÄ±nalÄ±ada</a>, and five smaller islandsâare part of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hisdic_18-3"><a href="#cite_note-hisdic-18">[15]</a></sup> Istanbul's shoreline has grown beyond its natural limits. Large sections of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caddebostan" title="Caddebostan">Caddebostan</a> sit on areas of landfill, increasing the total area of the city to 5,343 square kilometers (2,063Â sqÂ mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hisdic_18-4"><a href="#cite_note-hisdic-18">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite the myth that seven hills make up the city, there are, in fact, more than 50 hills within the city limits. Istanbul's tallest hill, Aydos, is 537 meters (1,762Â ft) high.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hisdic_18-5"><a href="#cite_note-hisdic-18">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>The nearby <a href="/wiki/North_Anatolian_Fault" title="North Anatolian Fault">North Anatolian Fault</a> is responsible for much earthquake activity, although it doesn't physically pass through the city itself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-econ1214_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-econ1214-96">[90]</a></sup> The fault caused the earthquakes in <a href="/wiki/1766_Istanbul_earthquake" title="1766 Istanbul earthquake">1766</a> and <a href="/wiki/1894_Istanbul_earthquake" title="1894 Istanbul earthquake">1894</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-econ1214_96-1"><a href="#cite_note-econ1214-96">[90]</a></sup> The threat of major earthquakes plays a large role in the city's infrastructure development, with over 500,000<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-econ1214_96-2"><a href="#cite_note-econ1214-96">[90]</a></sup> vulnerable buildings demolished and replaced since 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-earthquake_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-earthquake-97">[91]</a></sup> The city has repeatedly upgraded its <a href="/wiki/Building_code" title="Building code">building codes</a>, most recently in 2018,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-earthquake_97-1"><a href="#cite_note-earthquake-97">[91]</a></sup> requiring <a href="/wiki/Seismic_retrofit" title="Seismic retrofit">retrofits</a> for older buildings and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Safety_rating" title="Safety rating">higher engineering standards</a> for new construction.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_K%C3%B6ppen_Map.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="424" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="117" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Istanbul_K%C3%B6ppen_Map.png/220px-Istanbul_K%C3%B6ppen_Map.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Istanbul_K%C3%B6ppen_Map.png/330px-Istanbul_K%C3%B6ppen_Map.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Istanbul_K%C3%B6ppen_Map.png/440px-Istanbul_K%C3%B6ppen_Map.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_K%C3%B6ppen_Map.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Microclimates of Istanbul according to <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="KÃ¶ppen climate classification">KÃ¶ppenâGeiger classification system</a></div></div></div>
<p>Istanbul has a borderline <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">Mediterranean climate</a> (<a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="KÃ¶ppen climate classification">KÃ¶ppen</a> <i>Csa,</i> <a href="/wiki/Trewartha_climate_classification" title="Trewartha climate classification">Trewartha</a> <i>Cs</i>), <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate" title="Humid subtropical climate">humid subtropical climate</a> (KÃ¶ppen <i>Cfa,</i> Trewartha <i>Cf</i>) and <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">oceanic climate</a> (KÃ¶ppen <i>Cfb,</i> Trewartha <i>Do</i>) under both classifications. It experiences cool winters with frequent precipitation, and warm to hot (mean temperature peaking at 20Â Â°C (68Â Â°F) to 25Â Â°C (77Â Â°F) in August, depending on location), moderately dry summers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[92]</a></sup> Spring and fall are usually mild, with varying conditions dependent on wind direction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[94]</a></sup>
</p><p>Istanbul's weather is strongly influenced by the Sea of Marmara to the south, and the Black Sea to the north. This moderates temperature swings and produces a mild temperate climate with low <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diurnal_temperature_variation" title="Diurnal temperature variation">diurnal temperature variation</a>. Consequently, Istanbul's temperatures almost always oscillate between â5Â Â°C (23Â Â°F) and 32Â Â°C (90Â Â°F),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-101">[95]</a></sup> and most of the city does not experience temperatures above 30Â Â°C (86Â Â°F) for more than 14 days a year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-102">[96]</a></sup> Another effect of Istanbul's maritime position is its persistently high dew points, near-saturation morning humidity,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103"><a href="#cite_note-103">[97]</a></sup> and frequent fog,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[98]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_101-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-101">[95]</a></sup> which also limits Istanbul's sunshine hours to levels closer to Western Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[99]</a></sup>
</p><p>Because of its hilly topography and maritime influences, Istanbul exhibits a multitude of distinct <a href="/wiki/Microclimate" title="Microclimate">microclimates</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[100]</a></sup> Within the city, rainfall varies widely owing to the rain shadow of the hills in Istanbul, from around 600 millimeters (24Â in) on the southern fringe at <a href="/wiki/Florya" title="Florya">Florya</a> to 1,200 millimeters (47Â in) on the northern fringe at <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A7ek%C3%B6y,_Sar%C4%B1yer" title="BahÃ§ekÃ¶y, SarÄ±yer">BahÃ§ekÃ¶y</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[101]</a></sup> Furthermore, while the city itself lies in <a href="/wiki/Hardiness_zone" title="Hardiness zone">USDA hardiness zones</a> 9a to 9b, its inland suburbs lie in zone 8b with isolated pockets of zone 8a, restricting the cultivation of cold-hardy <a href="/wiki/Subtropics" title="Subtropics">subtropical</a> plants to the coasts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_102-1"><a href="#cite_note-:1-102">[96]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[102]</a></sup>
</p><p>As Istanbul is only slightly rain shadowed from Mediterranean storms and is otherwise surrounded by water, it usually receives some amount of precipitation from both Western European and Mediterranean <a href="/wiki/Extratropical_cyclone" title="Extratropical cyclone">systems</a>. This results in frequent precipitation during the winter months; January averages 20 days of precipitation when counting trace accumulations,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[103]</a></sup> 17 when using a 0.1Â mm threshold, and 12 when using a 1.0Â mm threshold.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[104]</a></sup> Precipitation is observed throughout the year; as 38% of the precipitation falls in winter, 18% in spring, 13% in summer, 31% in autumn. Summer is the driest season; However, unlike a true Mediterranean climate, there is no <a href="/wiki/Dry_season" title="Dry season">dry season</a>. The number of rainy days in the city is approximately 131 days, and in some parts it may reach up to 152 days.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[105]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to a study, an average of more than 60 centimeters (24Â in) of snow falls every year on the area of the <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Airport" title="Istanbul Airport">airport</a>, making Istanbul the snowiest major city in the Mediterranean basin, despite not having the cold winters typical of snowy cities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_101-2"><a href="#cite_note-:0-101">[95]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[106]</a></sup> Snowfall varies widely between years and different areas of the city, with districts facing north more prone to receive snow than southerly ones. This is largely caused by <a href="/wiki/Lake-effect_snow" title="Lake-effect snow">lake-effect snow</a>, which forms when cold Arctic maritime or Polar continental air, originating respectively from the <a href="/wiki/Polar_vortex" title="Polar vortex">North Pole</a> or <a href="/wiki/Siberian_High" title="Siberian High">Siberia</a>, develops into moist and unstable air that ascends to form snow squalls along the lee shores of the Black Sea, upon contact with the relatively warm water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mgm2020_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-mgm2020-113">[107]</a></sup> These snow squalls are heavy snow bands and occasionally thundersnows, with accumulation rates approaching 5â8 centimeters (2.0â3.1Â in) per hour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[108]</a></sup>
</p><p>The highest recorded temperature at the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_State_Meteorological_Service" title="Turkish State Meteorological Service">official</a> downtown observation station in <a href="/wiki/Sar%C4%B1yer" title="SarÄ±yer">SarÄ±yer</a> was 41.5Â Â°C (107Â Â°F) and on 13 July 2000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mgm2020_113-1"><a href="#cite_note-mgm2020-113">[107]</a></sup> The lowest recorded temperature was â16.1Â Â°C (3Â Â°F) on 9 February 1929.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mgm2020_113-2"><a href="#cite_note-mgm2020-113">[107]</a></sup> The highest recorded snow cover in the city center was 80 centimeters (31Â in) on 4 January 1942, and 104 centimeters (41Â in) in the northern suburbs on 11 January 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytsnow_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-nytsnow-115">[109]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mgm2020_113-3"><a href="#cite_note-mgm2020-113">[107]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[110]</a></sup>
</p>
