<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate_change">Climate change</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:M%C3%BCze_Gazhane_(2).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="4608" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/M%C3%BCze_Gazhane_%282%29.jpg/220px-M%C3%BCze_Gazhane_%282%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/M%C3%BCze_Gazhane_%282%29.jpg/330px-M%C3%BCze_Gazhane_%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/M%C3%BCze_Gazhane_%282%29.jpg/440px-M%C3%BCze_Gazhane_%282%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:M%C3%BCze_Gazhane_(2).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Hasanpa%C5%9Fa_Gasworks" title="HasanpaÅa Gasworks">MÃ¼ze Gazhane</a>  in <a href="/wiki/Kad%C4%B1k%C3%B6y" title="KadÄ±kÃ¶y">KadÄ±kÃ¶y</a> is the first climate change museum in Turkey.</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Turkey" title="Climate change in Turkey">Climate change in Turkey</a></div>
<p>As with virtually every part of the world, <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a> is causing more heatwaves,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[119]</a></sup> droughts,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[120]</a></sup> storms,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[121]</a></sup> and flooding<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[122]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CCTur_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-CCTur-129">[123]</a></sup> in Istanbul. Furthermore, as Istanbul is a large and rapidly expanding city, its <a href="/wiki/Urban_heat_island" title="Urban heat island">urban heat island</a> has been intensifying the effects of climate change.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_101-3"><a href="#cite_note-:0-101">[95]</a></sup> Considering past data,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[124]</a></sup> it is very likely that these two factors are responsible for urban Istanbul's shift, from a warm-summer climate to a hot-summer one in the KÃ¶ppen climate classification, and from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cool_temperate" title="Cool temperate">cool temperate</a> zone to the warm temperate/subtropical zone in the Trewartha climate classification.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[125]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[127]</a></sup> If trends continue, sea level rise is likely to affect city infrastructure, for example <a href="/wiki/Kad%C4%B1k%C3%B6y_(Istanbul_Metro)" title="KadÄ±kÃ¶y (Istanbul Metro)">KadÄ±koy metro station</a> is threatened with flooding.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[128]</a></sup>
<a href="/wiki/Xeriscaping" title="Xeriscaping">Xeriscaping</a> of green spaces has been suggested,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[129]</a></sup> and Istanbul has a climate-change action plan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[130]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Cityscape">Cityscape</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Districts_and_neighborhoods">Districts and neighborhoods</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Historic_Areas_of_Istanbul" title="Historic Areas of Istanbul">Historic Areas of Istanbul</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_urban_centers_in_Istanbul" title="List of urban centers in Istanbul">List of urban centers in Istanbul</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_Levent_skyline.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2044" data-file-width="3633" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Istanbul_Levent_skyline.jpg/220px-Istanbul_Levent_skyline.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Istanbul_Levent_skyline.jpg/330px-Istanbul_Levent_skyline.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Istanbul_Levent_skyline.jpg/440px-Istanbul_Levent_skyline.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_Levent_skyline.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A view of <a href="/wiki/Levent" title="Levent">Levent</a> from <a href="/wiki/Kanl%C4%B1ca" title="KanlÄ±ca">KanlÄ±ca</a> across the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bosphorus" title="Bosphorus">Bosphorus</a></div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="European_side">European side</span></h4>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Fatih" title="Fatih">Fatih</a> district, which was named after Sultan Mehmed II (<a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">Turkish</a>: <i>Fatih Sultan Mehmed</i>), corresponds to what was, until the Ottoman conquest in 1453, the whole of the city of Constantinople (today is the capital district and called the <i>historic peninsula</i> of Istanbul) on the southern shore of the Golden Horn, across the medieval <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Genoa" title="Republic of Genoa">Genoese</a> citadel of <a href="/wiki/Galata" title="Galata">Galata</a> on the northern shore. The Genoese fortifications in Galata were largely demolished in the 19th century, leaving only the <a href="/wiki/Galata_Tower" title="Galata Tower">Galata Tower</a>, to make way for the northward expansion of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[131]</a></sup> Galata (<a href="/wiki/Karak%C3%B6y" title="KarakÃ¶y">KarakÃ¶y</a>) is today a quarter within the <a href="/wiki/Beyo%C4%9Flu" title="BeyoÄlu">BeyoÄlu</a> (Pera) district, which forms Istanbul's commercial and entertainment center and includes <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0stiklal_Avenue" title="Ä°stiklal Avenue">Ä°stiklal Avenue</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taksim_Square" title="Taksim Square">Taksim Square</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[132]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace" title="DolmabahÃ§e Palace">DolmabahÃ§e Palace</a>, the seat of government during the late Ottoman period, is in the <a href="/wiki/Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F" title="BeÅiktaÅ">BeÅiktaÅ</a> district on the European shore of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bosphorus" title="Bosphorus">Bosphorus</a> strait, to the north of BeyoÄlu. The former village of <a href="/wiki/Ortak%C3%B6y" title="OrtakÃ¶y">OrtakÃ¶y</a> is within BeÅiktaÅ and gives its name to the <a href="/wiki/Ortak%C3%B6y_Mosque" title="OrtakÃ¶y Mosque">OrtakÃ¶y Mosque</a> on the Bosphorus, near the <a href="/wiki/Bosphorus_Bridge" title="Bosphorus Bridge">Bosphorus Bridge</a>. Lining both the European and Asian shores of the Bosphorus are the historic <i><a href="/wiki/Yal%C4%B1" title="YalÄ±">yalÄ±s</a></i>, luxurious chalet mansions built by Ottoman aristocrats and elites as summer homes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[133]</a></sup> Inland, north of Taksim Square is the <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Central_Business_District" title="Istanbul Central Business District">Istanbul Central Business District</a>, a set of corridors lined with office buildings, residential towers, shopping centers, and university campuses, and over 2,000,000Â m<sup>2</sup> (22,000,000Â sqÂ ft) of class-A office space in total. <a href="/wiki/Maslak" title="Maslak">Maslak</a>,  <a href="/wiki/Levent" title="Levent">Levent</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bomonti" title="Bomonti">Bomonti</a> are important nodes within the CBD.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOxford_Business_Group2009105_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOxford_Business_Group2009105-140">[134]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-property2021_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-property2021-141">[135]</a></sup>
</p><p>The AtatÃ¼rk Airport corridor is another such <a href="/wiki/Edge_city" title="Edge city">edge city</a>-style business, residential and shopping corridor with over 900,000Â m<sup>2</sup> (9,700,000Â sqÂ ft) of class-A office space.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-property2021_141-1"><a href="#cite_note-property2021-141">[135]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wooden_building_on_the_Bosphorus.jpg"><img alt="Two- and three-story colored houses with docks and balconies, built directly on the edge of the water" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3238" data-file-width="4579" decoding="async" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Wooden_building_on_the_Bosphorus.jpg/220px-Wooden_building_on_the_Bosphorus.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Wooden_building_on_the_Bosphorus.jpg/330px-Wooden_building_on_the_Bosphorus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Wooden_building_on_the_Bosphorus.jpg/440px-Wooden_building_on_the_Bosphorus.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Wooden_building_on_the_Bosphorus.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Originally outside the city, <i><a href="/wiki/Yal%C4%B1" title="YalÄ±">yalÄ±</a></i> residences along the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bosphorus" title="Bosphorus">Bosphorus</a> are now homes in some of Istanbul's elite neighborhoods.</div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Asian_side">Asian side</span></h4>
<p>During the Ottoman period, <a href="/wiki/%C3%9Csk%C3%BCdar" title="ÃskÃ¼dar">ÃskÃ¼dar</a> (then Scutari) and <a href="/wiki/Kad%C4%B1k%C3%B6y" title="KadÄ±kÃ¶y">KadÄ±kÃ¶y</a> were outside the scope of the urban area, serving as tranquil outposts with seaside <i>yalÄ±s</i> and gardens. But in the second half of the 20th century, the Asian side experienced major urban growth; the late development of this part of the city led to better infrastructure and tidier urban planning when compared with most other residential areas in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWCTR_SocietyUnÊ¼yu_Seisaku_KenkyÅ«_KikÅ2004281_142-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWCTR_SocietyUnÊ¼yu_Seisaku_KenkyÅ«_KikÅ2004281-142">[136]</a></sup> Much of the Asian side of the Bosphorus functions as a suburb of the economic and commercial centers in European Istanbul, accounting for a third of the city's population but only a quarter of its employment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWCTR_SocietyUnÊ¼yu_Seisaku_KenkyÅ«_KikÅ2004281_142-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWCTR_SocietyUnÊ¼yu_Seisaku_KenkyÅ«_KikÅ2004281-142">[136]</a></sup> However, <a href="/wiki/Kozyata%C4%9F%C4%B1" title="KozyataÄÄ±">KozyataÄÄ±</a>â<a href="/wiki/Ata%C5%9Fehir" title="AtaÅehir">AtaÅehir</a>, <a href="/wiki/Altunizade" title="Altunizade">Altunizade</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beykoz" title="Beykoz">Kavacik</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Umraniye" title="Umraniye">Umraniye</a>, all together having around 1.4 million sqm of class-A office space) are now important "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Edge_cities" title="Edge cities">edge cities</a>", i.e. corridors and nodes of business and shopping centers and of tall residential buildings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-property2021_141-2"><a href="#cite_note-property2021-141">[135]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Expansion">Expansion</span></h4>
<p>As a result of Istanbul's exponential growth in the 20th century, a significant portion of the city is composed of <i><a href="/wiki/Gecekondu" title="Gecekondu">gecekondus</a></i> (literally "built overnight"), referring to illegally constructed squatter buildings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kar7896_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-kar7896-143">[137]</a></sup> At present, some <i>gecekondu</i> areas are being gradually demolished and replaced by modern mass-housing compounds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yavuz_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-yavuz-144">[138]</a></sup> Moreover, large scale <a href="/wiki/Gentrification" title="Gentrification">gentrification</a> and <a href="/wiki/Urban_renewal" title="Urban renewal">urban renewal</a> projects have been taking place,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AtkinsonBridge2005_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-AtkinsonBridge2005-145">[139]</a></sup> such as the one in <a href="/wiki/Tarlaba%C5%9F%C4%B1" title="TarlabaÅÄ±">TarlabaÅÄ±</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[140]</a></sup> some of these projects, like the one in <a href="/wiki/Sulukule" title="Sulukule">Sulukule</a>, have faced criticism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[141]</a></sup> The Turkish government also has ambitious plans for an expansion of the city west and northwards on the European side in conjunction with the new <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_New_Airport" title="Istanbul New Airport">Istanbul Airport</a>, opened in 2019; the new parts of the city will include four different settlements with specified urban functions, housing 1.5Â million people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[142]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Parks">Parks</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Taksim_monument_and_mosque.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3024" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Taksim_monument_and_mosque.jpg/220px-Taksim_monument_and_mosque.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Taksim_monument_and_mosque.jpg/330px-Taksim_monument_and_mosque.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Taksim_monument_and_mosque.jpg/440px-Taksim_monument_and_mosque.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Taksim_monument_and_mosque.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A view of <a href="/wiki/Taksim_Square" title="Taksim Square">Taksim Square</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Republic_Monument" title="Republic Monument">Republic Monument</a> (1928) designed by Italian sculptor <a href="/wiki/Pietro_Canonica" title="Pietro Canonica">Pietro Canonica</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taksim_Mosque" title="Taksim Mosque">Taksim Mosque</a></div></div></div>
<p>Istanbul does not have a primary urban park, but it has several green areas. <a href="/wiki/G%C3%BClhane_Park" title="GÃ¼lhane Park">GÃ¼lhane Park</a> and <a href="/wiki/Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1z_Park" title="YÄ±ldÄ±z Park">YÄ±ldÄ±z Park</a> were originally included within the grounds of two of Istanbul's palaces â TopkapÄ± Palace and <a href="/wiki/Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1z_Palace" title="YÄ±ldÄ±z Palace">YÄ±ldÄ±z Palace</a>âbut they were repurposed as public parks in the early decades of the Turkish Republic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[143]</a></sup> Another park, <a href="/wiki/Fethi_Pa%C5%9Fa_Korusu" title="Fethi PaÅa Korusu">Fethi PaÅa Korusu</a>, is on a hillside adjacent to the Bosphorus Bridge in Anatolia, opposite YÄ±ldÄ±z Palace in Europe. Along the European side, and close to the <a href="/wiki/Fatih_Sultan_Mehmet_Bridge" title="Fatih Sultan Mehmet Bridge">Fatih Sultan Mehmet Bridge</a>, is <a href="/wiki/Emirgan_Park" title="Emirgan Park">Emirgan Park</a>, which was known as the <i>Kyparades</i> (<a href="/wiki/Cypress" title="Cypress">Cypress</a> Forest) during the Byzantine period. In the Ottoman period, it was first granted to <a href="/wiki/Lord_Chancellor" title="Lord Chancellor">NiÅancÄ±</a> <a href="/wiki/Feridun_Ahmed_Bey" title="Feridun Ahmed Bey">Feridun Ahmed Bey</a> in the 16th century, before being granted by Sultan <a href="/wiki/Murad_IV" title="Murad IV">Murad IV</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Safavid_dynasty" title="Safavid dynasty">Safavid</a> <a href="/wiki/Emir" title="Emir">Emir</a> GÃ»ne Han in the 17th century, hence the name <i>Emirgan</i>. The 47-hectare (120-acre) park was later owned by <a href="/wiki/Khedive" title="Khedive">Khedive</a> <a href="/wiki/Isma%27il_Pasha" title="Isma'il Pasha">Ismail Pasha</a> of <a href="/wiki/Khedivate_of_Egypt" title="Khedivate of Egypt">Ottoman Egypt and Sudan</a> in the 19th century. Emirgan Park is known for its diversity of plants and an annual <a href="/wiki/Tulip" title="Tulip">tulip</a> festival is held there since 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[144]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Justice_and_Development_Party_(Turkey)" title="Justice and Development Party (Turkey)">AKP</a> government's decision to replace <a href="/wiki/Taksim_Gezi_Park" title="Taksim Gezi Park">Taksim Gezi Park</a> with a replica of the Ottoman era <a href="/wiki/Taksim_Military_Barracks" title="Taksim Military Barracks">Taksim Military Barracks</a> (which was transformed into the <a href="/wiki/Taksim_Stadium" title="Taksim Stadium">Taksim Stadium</a> in 1921, before being demolished in 1940 for building Gezi Park) sparked a series of <a href="/wiki/Gezi_Park_protests" title="Gezi Park protests">nationwide protests in 2013</a> covering a wide range of issues. Popular during the summer among Istanbulites is <a href="/wiki/Belgrad_Forest" title="Belgrad Forest">Belgrad Forest</a>, spreading across 5,500 hectares (14,000 acres) at the northern edge of the city. The forest originally supplied water to the city and remnants of reservoirs used during Byzantine and Ottoman times survive.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[145]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[146]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:808px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_panorama_and_skyline.jpg" title="Panoramic view of Istanbul from the confluence of the Bosphorus and the Sea of Marmara. Several landmarksâincluding Sultan Ahmed Mosque, the Hagia Sophia, TopkapÄ± Palace, and DolmabahÃ§e Palaceâcan be seen along their shores."><img alt="" data-file-height="1123" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Istanbul_panorama_and_skyline.jpg/800px-Istanbul_panorama_and_skyline.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Istanbul_panorama_and_skyline.jpg/1200px-Istanbul_panorama_and_skyline.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Istanbul_panorama_and_skyline.jpg/1600px-Istanbul_panorama_and_skyline.jpg 2x" width="800"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:center"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_panorama_and_skyline.jpg" title="File:Istanbul panorama and skyline.jpg"> </a></div>Panoramic view of Istanbul from the confluence of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bosphorus" title="Bosphorus">Bosphorus</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Marmara" title="Sea of Marmara">Sea of Marmara</a>. Several landmarksâincluding <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque" title="Sultan Ahmed Mosque">Sultan Ahmed Mosque</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Hagia_Sophia" title="Hagia Sophia">Hagia Sophia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Topkap%C4%B1_Palace" title="TopkapÄ± Palace">TopkapÄ± Palace</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace" title="DolmabahÃ§e Palace">DolmabahÃ§e Palace</a>âcan be seen along their shores.</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Istanbul" title="Architecture of Istanbul">Architecture of Istanbul</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_architecture" title="Ottoman architecture">Ottoman architecture</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Turkey" title="Architecture of Turkey">Architecture of Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_asv2020-02_img48_Galata_Tower.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="6482" data-file-width="4321" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Istanbul_asv2020-02_img48_Galata_Tower.jpg/170px-Istanbul_asv2020-02_img48_Galata_Tower.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Istanbul_asv2020-02_img48_Galata_Tower.jpg/255px-Istanbul_asv2020-02_img48_Galata_Tower.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Istanbul_asv2020-02_img48_Galata_Tower.jpg/340px-Istanbul_asv2020-02_img48_Galata_Tower.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_asv2020-02_img48_Galata_Tower.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Galata_Tower" title="Galata Tower">Galata Tower</a> dominates the skyline of the medieval <a href="/wiki/Galata" title="Galata">Genoese citadel</a> at the north of the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horn" title="Golden Horn">Golden Horn</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Istanbul is primarily known for its Byzantine and Ottoman architecture. Despite its development as a Turkish city since 1453, it contains many ancient, Roman, Byzantine, Christian, Muslim, and Jewish monuments.
</p><p>The Neolithic settlement in the <a href="/wiki/Yenikap%C4%B1" title="YenikapÄ±">YenikapÄ±</a> quarter on the European side, which dates back to c. 6500 BCE and predates the formation of the <a href="/wiki/Bosporus" title="Bosporus">Bosporus</a> strait by approximately a millennium (when the Sea of Marmara was still a lake)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[147]</a></sup> was discovered during the construction of the <a href="/wiki/Marmaray" title="Marmaray">Marmaray</a> railway tunnel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC-Rainsford-2009_29-2"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-Rainsford-2009-29">[26]</a></sup> It is the oldest known human settlement on the European side of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC-Rainsford-2009_29-3"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-Rainsford-2009-29">[26]</a></sup> The oldest known human settlement on the Asian side is the Fikirtepe Mound near KadÄ±kÃ¶y, with relics dating to c. 5500-3500 BCE (<a href="/wiki/Chalcolithic" title="Chalcolithic">Chalcolithic</a> period).
</p><p>There are numerous ancient monuments in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-coaot_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-coaot-154">[148]</a></sup> The most ancient is the <a href="/wiki/Obelisk" title="Obelisk">Obelisk</a> of <a href="/wiki/Thutmose_III" title="Thutmose III">Thutmose III</a> (<a href="/wiki/Obelisk_of_Theodosius" title="Obelisk of Theodosius">Obelisk of Theodosius</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-coaot_154-1"><a href="#cite_note-coaot-154">[148]</a></sup> Built of red granite, 31Â m (100Â ft) high, it came from the <a href="/wiki/Karnak" title="Karnak">Temple of Karnak</a> in <a href="/wiki/Luxor" title="Luxor">Luxor</a>, and was erected there by <a href="/wiki/Pharaoh" title="Pharaoh">Pharaoh</a> Thutmose III (r. 1479â1425 BCE) to the south of the seventh <a href="/wiki/Pylon_(architecture)" title="Pylon (architecture)">pylon</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-coaot_154-2"><a href="#cite_note-coaot-154">[148]</a></sup> The Roman emperor <a href="/wiki/Constantius_II" title="Constantius II">Constantius II</a> (r. 337â361 CE) had it and another obelisk transported along the River <a href="/wiki/Nile" title="Nile">Nile</a> to <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a> for commemorating his <i>ventennalia</i> or 20 years on the throne in 357. The other obelisk was erected on the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spina_(Roman_circus)" title="Spina (Roman circus)">spina</a></i> of the <a href="/wiki/Circus_Maximus" title="Circus Maximus">Circus Maximus</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rome" title="Rome">Rome</a> in the autumn of that year, and is now known as the <a href="/wiki/Lateran_Obelisk" title="Lateran Obelisk">Lateran Obelisk</a>. The obelisk that would become the <i>Obelisk of Theodosius</i> remained in Alexandria until 390 CE, when Theodosius I (r. 379â395 CE) had it transported to Constantinople and put up on the <i>spina</i> of the Hippodrome there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Habachi_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-Habachi-155">[149]</a></sup> When re-erected at the Hippodrome of Constantinople, the obelisk was mounted on a decorative base, with <a href="/wiki/Relief" title="Relief">reliefs</a> that depict Theodosius I and his courtiers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-coaot_154-3"><a href="#cite_note-coaot-154">[148]</a></sup> The lower part of the obelisk was damaged in antiquity, probably during its transport to Alexandria in 357 CE or during its re-erection at the Hippodrome of Constantinople in 390 CE. As a result, the current height of the obelisk is only 18.54 meters, or 25.6 meters if the base is included. Between the four corners of the obelisk and the pedestal are four bronze cubes, used in its transportation and re-erection.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wallis_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wallis-156">[150]</a></sup>
</p><p>Next in age is the <a href="/wiki/Serpent_Column" title="Serpent Column">Serpent Column</a>, from 479 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-coaot_154-4"><a href="#cite_note-coaot-154">[148]</a></sup> It was brought from <a href="/wiki/Delphi" title="Delphi">Delphi</a> in 324 CE, during the reign of Constantine the Great, and also erected at the <i>spina</i> of the Hippodrome.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-coaot_154-5"><a href="#cite_note-coaot-154">[148]</a></sup> It was originally part of an <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">ancient Greek</a> <a href="/wiki/Sacrificial_tripod" title="Sacrificial tripod">sacrificial tripod</a> in Delphi that was erected to commemorate the Greeks who fought and defeated the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Persian_Empire" title="Persian Empire">Persian Empire</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Plataea" title="Battle of Plataea">Battle of Plataea</a> (479 BCE). The three serpent heads of the 8-meter (26Â ft) high column remained intact until the end of the 17th century (one is on display at the nearby <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Archaeology_Museums" title="Istanbul Archaeology Museums">Istanbul Archaeology Museums</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p>Built in <a href="/wiki/Porphyry_(geology)" title="Porphyry (geology)">porphyry</a> and erected at the center of the <a href="/wiki/Forum_of_Constantine" title="Forum of Constantine">Forum of Constantine</a> in 330 CE to mark the founding of the new Roman capital, the <a href="/wiki/Column_of_Constantine" title="Column of Constantine">Column of Constantine</a> was originally adorned with a sculpture of the Roman emperor Constantine the Great depicted as the solar god <a href="/wiki/Apollo" title="Apollo">Apollo</a> on its top, which fell in 1106 and was later replaced by a cross during the reign of Byzantine emperor <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manuel_Komnenos" title="Manuel Komnenos">Manuel Komnenos</a> (r. 1143â1180).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forum_of_Constantine_20-2"><a href="#cite_note-Forum_of_Constantine-20">[17]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-coaot_154-6"><a href="#cite_note-coaot-154">[148]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace,_Istanbul_cropped.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2484" data-file-width="4740" decoding="async" height="105" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace%2C_Istanbul_cropped.jpg/200px-Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace%2C_Istanbul_cropped.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace%2C_Istanbul_cropped.jpg/300px-Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace%2C_Istanbul_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace%2C_Istanbul_cropped.jpg/400px-Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace%2C_Istanbul_cropped.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ciragan_Palace_2014.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="4912" data-file-width="7360" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Ciragan_Palace_2014.JPG/200px-Ciragan_Palace_2014.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Ciragan_Palace_2014.JPG/300px-Ciragan_Palace_2014.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Ciragan_Palace_2014.JPG/400px-Ciragan_Palace_2014.JPG 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_Beylerbeyi_Palace_IMG_7663_1805.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1805" data-file-width="3002" decoding="async" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Istanbul_Beylerbeyi_Palace_IMG_7663_1805.jpg/200px-Istanbul_Beylerbeyi_Palace_IMG_7663_1805.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Istanbul_Beylerbeyi_Palace_IMG_7663_1805.jpg/300px-Istanbul_Beylerbeyi_Palace_IMG_7663_1805.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Istanbul_Beylerbeyi_Palace_IMG_7663_1805.jpg/400px-Istanbul_Beylerbeyi_Palace_IMG_7663_1805.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_Bosphorus_K%C3%BC%C3%A7%C3%BCksu_Palace_IMG_7764_1920.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2881" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Istanbul_Bosphorus_K%C3%BC%C3%A7%C3%BCksu_Palace_IMG_7764_1920.jpg/200px-Istanbul_Bosphorus_K%C3%BC%C3%A7%C3%BCksu_Palace_IMG_7764_1920.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Istanbul_Bosphorus_K%C3%BC%C3%A7%C3%BCksu_Palace_IMG_7764_1920.jpg/300px-Istanbul_Bosphorus_K%C3%BC%C3%A7%C3%BCksu_Palace_IMG_7764_1920.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Istanbul_Bosphorus_K%C3%BC%C3%A7%C3%BCksu_Palace_IMG_7764_1920.jpg/400px-Istanbul_Bosphorus_K%C3%BC%C3%A7%C3%BCksu_Palace_IMG_7764_1920.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Built by Ottoman sultans <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abd%C3%BClmecid_I" title="AbdÃ¼lmecid I">AbdÃ¼lmecid</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abd%C3%BClaziz_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="AbdÃ¼laziz of the Ottoman Empire">AbdÃ¼laziz</a>, the 19th-century <a href="/wiki/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace" title="DolmabahÃ§e Palace">DolmabahÃ§e</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C3%87%C4%B1ra%C4%9Fan_Palace" title="ÃÄ±raÄan Palace">ÃÄ±raÄan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beylerbeyi_Palace" title="Beylerbeyi Palace">Beylerbeyi</a> and <a href="/wiki/K%C3%BC%C3%A7%C3%BCksu_Pavilion" title="KÃ¼Ã§Ã¼ksu Pavilion">KÃ¼Ã§Ã¼ksu</a> palaces on the <a href="/wiki/Bosporus" title="Bosporus">Bosporus</a> were designed by members of the Armenian <a href="/wiki/Balyan_family" title="Balyan family">Balyan family</a> of court architects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[152]</a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>There are traces of the Byzantine era throughout the city, from ancient churches that were built over early Christian meeting places like the <a href="/wiki/Hagia_Irene" title="Hagia Irene">Hagia Irene</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Chora_Church" title="Chora Church">Chora Church</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Monastery_of_Stoudios" title="Monastery of Stoudios">Monastery of Stoudios</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Little_Hagia_Sophia" title="Little Hagia Sophia">Church of Sts. Sergius and Bacchus</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pammakaristos_Church" title="Pammakaristos Church">Church of Theotokos Pammakaristos</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Zeyrek_Mosque" title="Zeyrek Mosque">Monastery of the Pantocrator</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Eski_Imaret_Mosque" title="Eski Imaret Mosque">Monastery of Christ Pantepoptes</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G%C3%BCl_Mosque" title="GÃ¼l Mosque">Hagia Theodosia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Kalenderhane_Mosque" title="Kalenderhane Mosque">Church of Theotokos Kyriotissa</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Fenari_Isa_Mosque" title="Fenari Isa Mosque">Monastery of Constantine Lips</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bodrum_Mosque" title="Bodrum Mosque">Church of Myrelaion</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Church-Mosque_of_Vefa" title="Church-Mosque of Vefa">Hagios Theodoros</a>, etc.; to palaces like the Great Palace of Constantinople and its <a href="/wiki/Great_Palace_Mosaic_Museum" title="Great Palace Mosaic Museum">Mosaic Museum</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_the_Porphyrogenitus" title="Palace of the Porphyrogenitus">Palace of the Porphyrogenitus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boukoleon_Palace" title="Boukoleon Palace">Boukoleon Palace</a> and <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Blachernae" title="Palace of Blachernae">Palace of Blachernae</a>; and other public places and buildings like the Hippodrome, the <a href="/wiki/Augustaion" title="Augustaion">Augustaion</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Basilica_Cistern" title="Basilica Cistern">Basilica Cistern</a>, <a href="/wiki/Theodosius_Cistern" title="Theodosius Cistern">Theodosius Cistern</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cistern_of_Philoxenos" title="Cistern of Philoxenos">Cistern of Philoxenos</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cistern_of_the_Hebdomon" title="Cistern of the Hebdomon">Cistern of the Hebdomon</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Aqueduct_of_Valens" title="Aqueduct of Valens">Aqueduct of Valens</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Prison_of_Anemas" title="Prison of Anemas">Prison of Anemas</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Walls_of_Constantinople" title="Walls of Constantinople">Walls of Constantinople</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Porta_Aurea" title="Porta Aurea">Porta Aurea</a> (Golden Gate), among numerous others. The 4th century <a href="/wiki/Harbour_of_Eleutherios" title="Harbour of Eleutherios">Harbor of Theodosius</a> in YenikapÄ±, once the busiest port in Constantinople, was among the numerous archeological discoveries that took place during the excavations of the Marmaray tunnel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC-Rainsford-2009_29-4"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-Rainsford-2009-29">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p>However, it is the Hagia Sophia that fully conveys the period of Constantinople as a city without parallel in <a href="/wiki/Christendom" title="Christendom">Christendom</a>. The Hagia Sophia, topped by a dome 31 meters (102Â ft) in diameter over a square space defined by four arches, is the pinnacle of <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">Byzantine architecture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mangocyril_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-mangocyril-159">[153]</a></sup> The Hagia Sophia stood as the world's largest cathedral in the world until it was converted into a mosque in the 15th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mangocyril_159-1"><a href="#cite_note-mangocyril-159">[153]</a></sup> The minarets date from that period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mangocyril_159-2"><a href="#cite_note-mangocyril-159">[153]</a></sup> Because of its historical significance, it was reopened as a museum in 1935. However, it was re-converted into a mosque in July 2020.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sultanahmet_Camii,_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2319" data-file-width="3092" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Sultanahmet_Camii%2C_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg/220px-Sultanahmet_Camii%2C_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Sultanahmet_Camii%2C_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg/330px-Sultanahmet_Camii%2C_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Sultanahmet_Camii%2C_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg/440px-Sultanahmet_Camii%2C_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sultanahmet_Camii,_%C4%B0stanbul.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque" title="Sultan Ahmed Mosque">Sultan Ahmed Mosque</a> is known as the <i>Blue Mosque</i> due to the blue <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%B0znik_tiles" title="Ä°znik tiles">Ä°znik tiles</a> which adorn its interior.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bluemosque_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-bluemosque-160">[154]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Obelisk" title="Obelisk">Obelisk</a> of <a href="/wiki/Thutmose_III" title="Thutmose III">Thutmose III</a> (<a href="/wiki/Obelisk_of_Theodosius" title="Obelisk of Theodosius">Obelisk of Theodosius</a>) is seen in the foreground.</div></div></div>
<p>Over the next four centuries, the Ottomans transformed Istanbul's urban landscape with a vast building scheme that included the construction of towering mosques and ornate palaces. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sultan_Ahmed_Mosque" title="Sultan Ahmed Mosque">Sultan Ahmed Mosque</a> (Blue Mosque), another landmark of the city, faces the Hagia Sophia at Sultanahmet Square (Hippodrome of Constantinople). The <a href="/wiki/S%C3%BCleymaniye_Mosque" title="SÃ¼leymaniye Mosque">SÃ¼leymaniye Mosque</a>, built by Suleiman the Magnificent, was designed by his chief architect Mimar Sinan, the most illustrious of all Ottoman architects, who designed many of the city's renowned mosques and other types of public buildings and monuments.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sinan-britannica_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-sinan-britannica-161">[155]</a></sup>
</p><p>Among the oldest surviving examples of <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_architecture" title="Ottoman architecture">Ottoman architecture</a> in Istanbul are the <a href="/wiki/Anadoluhisar%C4%B1" title="AnadoluhisarÄ±">AnadoluhisarÄ±</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rumelihisar%C4%B1" title="RumelihisarÄ±">RumelihisarÄ±</a> fortresses, which assisted the Ottomans during their siege of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[156]</a></sup> Over the next four centuries, the Ottomans made an indelible impression on the skyline of Istanbul, building towering mosques and ornate palaces.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1817" data-file-width="3635" decoding="async" height="110" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg/220px-Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg/330px-Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg/440px-Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Topkap%C4%B1_-_01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A view of <a href="/wiki/Topkap%C4%B1_Palace" title="TopkapÄ± Palace">TopkapÄ± Palace</a>, the inner core of which was built in 1459â1465, from across the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horn" title="Golden Horn">Golden Horn</a>, with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prince_Islands" title="Prince Islands">Prince Islands</a> in the background</div></div></div>
<p>TopkapÄ± Palace, dating back to 1465, is the oldest seat of government surviving in Istanbul. Mehmed II built the original palace as his main residence and the seat of government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freely_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-freely-163">[157]</a></sup> The present palace grew over the centuries as a series of additions enfolding four courtyards and blending <a href="/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture" title="Neoclassical architecture">neoclassical</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rococo" title="Rococo">rococo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Baroque_architecture" title="Baroque architecture">baroque</a> architectural forms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wharton_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-wharton-164">[158]</a></sup> In 1639, Murad IV made some of the most lavish additions, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baghdad_Kiosk" title="Baghdad Kiosk">Baghdad Kiosk</a>, to commemorate his <a href="/wiki/Capture_of_Baghdad_(1638)" title="Capture of Baghdad (1638)">conquest of Baghdad</a> the previous year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-necipoglu_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-necipoglu-165">[159]</a></sup> Government meetings took place here until 1786, when the seat of government was moved to the Sublime Porte.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freely_163-1"><a href="#cite_note-freely-163">[157]</a></sup> After several hundred years of royal residence, it was abandoned in 1853 in favor of the baroque DolmabahÃ§e Palace.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wharton_164-1"><a href="#cite_note-wharton-164">[158]</a></sup> TopkapÄ± Palace became public property following the <a href="/wiki/Abolition_of_monarchy" title="Abolition of monarchy">abolition of monarchy</a> in 1922.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wharton_164-2"><a href="#cite_note-wharton-164">[158]</a></sup> After extensive renovation, it became one of Turkey's first national museums in 1924.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-freely_163-2"><a href="#cite_note-freely-163">[157]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mosques_commissioned_by_the_Ottoman_dynasty" title="Mosques commissioned by the Ottoman dynasty">imperial mosques</a> include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fatih_Mosque" title="Fatih Mosque">Fatih Mosque</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bayezid_Mosque" title="Bayezid Mosque">Bayezid Mosque</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yavuz_Selim_Mosque" title="Yavuz Selim Mosque">Yavuz Selim Mosque</a>, SÃ¼leymaniye Mosque, Sultan Ahmed Mosque (the Blue Mosque), and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Mosque_(Istanbul)" title="New Mosque (Istanbul)">Yeni Mosque</a>, all of which were built at the peak of the Ottoman Empire, in the 16th and 17th centuries. In the following centuries, and especially after the <i><a href="/wiki/Tanzimat" title="Tanzimat">Tanzimat</a></i> reforms, Ottoman architecture was supplanted by European styles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[160]</a></sup> An example of which is the imperial <a href="/wiki/Nuruosmaniye_Mosque" title="Nuruosmaniye Mosque">Nuruosmaniye Mosque</a>. Areas around Ä°stiklal Avenue were filled with grand European embassies and rows of buildings in Neoclassical, <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_Revival_architecture" title="Renaissance Revival architecture">Renaissance Revival</a> and <a href="/wiki/Art_Nouveau" title="Art Nouveau">Art Nouveau</a> styles, which went on to influence the architecture of a variety of structures in BeyoÄluâincluding churches, stores, and theatersâand official buildings such as DolmabahÃ§e Palace.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[161]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Administration">Administration</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/List_of_districts_of_Istanbul" title="List of districts of Istanbul">List of districts of Istanbul</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_neighborhoods_of_Istanbul" title="List of neighborhoods of Istanbul">List of neighborhoods of Istanbul</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_location_districts.svg"><img alt="A map depicting districts, squeezed between two bodies of water; farther districts are very large compared to those clustered in the center." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="276" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Istanbul_location_districts.svg/300px-Istanbul_location_districts.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Istanbul_location_districts.svg/450px-Istanbul_location_districts.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/Istanbul_location_districts.svg/600px-Istanbul_location_districts.svg.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_location_districts.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Istanbul's districts extend far from the city center, along the full length of the Bosphorus (with the Black Sea at the top and the Sea of Marmara at the bottom of the map).</div></div></div>
<p>Since 2004, the municipal boundaries of Istanbul have been coincident with the boundaries of its province.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[162]</a></sup> The city, considered capital of the larger Istanbul Province, is administered by the Istanbul Metropolitan Municipality (MMI), which oversees the <a href="/wiki/List_of_districts_of_Istanbul" title="List of districts of Istanbul">39 districts</a> of the city-province.
</p><p>The current city structure can be traced back to the <i>Tanzimat</i> period of reform in the 19th century, before which <a href="/wiki/Qadi" title="Qadi">Islamic judges</a> and imams led the city under the auspices of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grand_Vizier" title="Grand Vizier">Grand Vizier</a>. Following the model of French cities, this religious system was replaced by a mayor and a citywide council composed of representatives of the confessional groups (<i><a href="/wiki/Millet_(Ottoman_Empire)" title="Millet (Ottoman Empire)">millet</a></i>) across the city. Pera (now BeyoÄlu) was the first area of the city to have its own director and council, with members instead being longtime residents of the neighborhood.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[163]</a></sup> Laws enacted after the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ottoman_constitution_of_1876" title="Ottoman constitution of 1876">Ottoman constitution of 1876</a> aimed to expand this structure across the city, imitating the twenty <a href="/wiki/Arrondissements_of_Paris" title="Arrondissements of Paris">arrondissements of Paris</a>, but they were not fully implemented until 1908 when the city was declared a province with nine constituent districts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[164]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[165]</a></sup> This system continued beyond the founding of the Turkish Republic, with the province renamed a <i>belediye</i> (municipality), but the municipality was disbanded in 1957.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[166]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BuyukadaMainSquare.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2268" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/BuyukadaMainSquare.jpg/220px-BuyukadaMainSquare.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/BuyukadaMainSquare.jpg/330px-BuyukadaMainSquare.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/BuyukadaMainSquare.jpg/440px-BuyukadaMainSquare.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BuyukadaMainSquare.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Statue of <a href="/wiki/Mustafa_Kemal_Atat%C3%BCrk" title="Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk">AtatÃ¼rk</a> in <a href="/wiki/B%C3%BCy%C3%BCkada" title="BÃ¼yÃ¼kada">BÃ¼yÃ¼kada</a>, the largest of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prince_Islands" title="Prince Islands">Prince Islands</a> to the southeast of Istanbul, which collectively form the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Adalar" title="Adalar">Adalar (<i>Isles</i>)</a> district of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_Province" title="Istanbul Province">Istanbul Province</a></div></div></div>
<p>Small settlements adjacent to major population centers in Turkey, including Istanbul, were merged into their respective primary cities during the early 1980s, resulting in metropolitan municipalities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[167]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[168]</a></sup> The main decision-making body of the Istanbul Metropolitan Municipality is the Municipal Council, with members drawn from district councils.
</p><p>The Municipal Council is responsible for citywide issues, including managing the budget, maintaining civic infrastructure, and overseeing museums and major cultural centers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kapa1535_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-kapa1535-175">[169]</a></sup> Since the government operates under a "powerful mayor, weak council" approach, the council's leaderâthe metropolitan mayorâhas the authority to make swift decisions, often at the expense of transparency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[170]</a></sup> The Municipal Council is advised by the Metropolitan Executive Committee, although the committee also has limited power to make decisions of its own.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kapa156_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-kapa156-177">[171]</a></sup> All representatives on the committee are appointed by the metropolitan mayor and the council, with the mayorâor someone of his or her choosingâserving as head.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kapa156_177-1"><a href="#cite_note-kapa156-177">[171]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mmi-mec_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-mmi-mec-178">[172]</a></sup>
</p><p>District councils are chiefly responsible for waste management and construction projects within their respective districts. They each maintain their own budgets, although the metropolitan mayor reserves the right to review district decisions. One-fifth of all district council members, including the district mayors, also represent their districts in the Municipal Council.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kapa1535_175-1"><a href="#cite_note-kapa1535-175">[169]</a></sup> All members of the district councils and the Municipal Council, including the metropolitan mayor, are elected to five-year terms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[173]</a></sup> Representing the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republican_People%27s_Party_(Turkey)" title="Republican People's Party (Turkey)">Republican People's Party</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ekrem_%C4%B0mamo%C4%9Flu" title="Ekrem Ä°mamoÄlu">Ekrem Ä°mamoÄlu</a> has been the <a href="/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Istanbul" title="List of mayors of Istanbul">Mayor of Istanbul</a> since <a href="/wiki/June_2019_Istanbul_mayoral_election" title="June 2019 Istanbul mayoral election">27 June 2019</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[174]</a></sup>
</p><p>With the Istanbul Metropolitan Municipality and Istanbul Province having equivalent jurisdictions, few responsibilities remain for the provincial government. Like the MMI, the Istanbul Special Provincial Administration has a governor, a democratically elected decision-making bodyâthe Provincial Parliamentâand an appointed Executive Committee. Mirroring the executive committee at the municipal level, the Provincial Executive Committee includes a secretary-general and leaders of departments that advise the Provincial Parliament.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mmi-mec_178-1"><a href="#cite_note-mmi-mec-178">[172]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[175]</a></sup> The Provincial Administration's duties are largely limited to the building and maintenance of schools, residences, government buildings, and roads, and the promotion of arts, culture, and nature conservation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[176]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ali_Yerlikaya" title="Ali Yerlikaya">Ali Yerlikaya</a> has been the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Governors_of_Istanbul_Province" title="List of Governors of Istanbul Province">Governor of Istanbul Province</a> since 26 October 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[177]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Istanbul" title="Demographics of Istanbul">Demographics of Istanbul</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Turkey" title="Demographics of Turkey">Demographics of Turkey</a></div>
<table class="toccolours" style="clear: right; float: right; border-spacing: 0; margin-left: 1em;">
<caption><span style="font-size:110%;"><b>Historical populations</b></span>
</caption>

<td style="border-left:solid 1px black; padding-left:0.2em">
<table class="toccolours" style="width:15em;border-top-width:0;margin:0;border-collapse:collapse;border:none;"><caption style="border-top:1px #aaa solid;border-left:1px #aaa solid;border-right:1px style="text-align:center;padding:1px"> 1990</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">6,620,200</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+3.80%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px"> 1994</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">7,615,500</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+3.56%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb"> 1997</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">8,260,400</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">+2.75%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px"> 2000</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">8,831,800</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+2.25%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px"> 2007</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">11,174,200</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+3.42%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px"> 2015</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">14,657,434</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+3.45%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px"> 2016</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">14,804,116</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+1.00%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb"> 2017</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">15,029,231</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px;border-bottom:1px solid #bbbbbb">+1.52%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px"> 2018</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">15,067,724</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+0.26%</td></tr><tr><th style="text-align:center;padding:1px"> 2019</th><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">15,519,267</td><td style="text-align:right;padding:1px">+3.00%</td></tr></tbody></table>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="font-size:100%; text-align:center">Sources: Jan Lahmeyer 2004,<a href="#CITEREFChandler1987">Chandler 1987</a>, <a href="#CITEREFMorris2010">Morris 2010</a>,<a href="#CITEREFTuran2010">Turan 2010</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mfa_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-mfa-184">[178]</a></sup><br/> Pre-Republic figures estimated<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pop-figures_64-1"><a href="#cite_note-pop-figures-64">[e]</a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Throughout most of its history, Istanbul has ranked among the largest cities in the world. By 500 CE, Constantinople had somewhere between 400,000 and 500,000 people, edging out its predecessor, Rome, for the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_cities_throughout_history" title="List of largest cities throughout history">world's largest city</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[180]</a></sup> Constantinople jostled with other major historical cities, such as <a href="/wiki/Baghdad" title="Baghdad">Baghdad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chang%27an" title="Chang'an">Chang'an</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kaifeng" title="Kaifeng">Kaifeng</a> and <a href="/wiki/Merv" title="Merv">Merv</a> for the position of the world's largest city until the 12th century. It never returned to being the world's largest, but remained the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_European_cities_in_history" title="List of largest European cities in history">largest city</a> in Europe from 1500 to 1750, when it was surpassed by <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cha463_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-cha463-187">[181]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Statistical_Institute" title="Turkish Statistical Institute">Turkish Statistical Institute</a> estimates that the population of Istanbul Metropolitan Municipality was 15,519,267 at the end of 2019, hosting <span class="nowrap">19 percent</span> of the country's population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tuikpop_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-tuikpop-188">[182]</a></sup> 64.4% of the residents live on the European side and 35.6% on the Asian side.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tuikpop_188-1"><a href="#cite_note-tuikpop-188">[182]</a></sup>
</p><p>Istanbul ranks as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_cities_proper_by_population" title="List of cities proper by population">seventh-largest city proper</a> in the world, and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_Europe" title="List of metropolitan areas in Europe">second-largest urban agglomeration</a> in Europe, after <a href="/wiki/Moscow_metropolitan_area" title="Moscow metropolitan area">Moscow</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[184]</a></sup> The city's annual population growth of <span class="nowrap">1.5 percent</span> ranks as one of the highest among the seventy-eight largest metropolises in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a>. The high population growth mirrors an urbanization trend across the country, as the second and third fastest-growing <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> metropolises are the Turkish cities of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Izmir" title="Izmir">Izmir</a> and Ankara.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecd_19-1"><a href="#cite_note-oecd-19">[16]</a></sup>
</p><p>Istanbul experienced especially rapid growth during the second half of the 20th century, with its population increasing tenfold between 1950 and 2000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tu224_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-tu224-191">[185]</a></sup> This growth was fueled by internal and international migration. Istanbul's foreign population with a residence permit increased dramatically, from 43,000 in 2007<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[186]</a></sup> to 856,377 in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-immig_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-immig-193">[187]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-immigft_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-immigft-194">[188]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to 2020 TÃÄ°K data around 2.1 million people in a population of over 15.4 million have been registered<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[g]</a></sup> in Istanbul, meanwhile the vast majority of the residents ultimately originate from Anatolian provinces, especially those in the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea_Region" title="Black Sea Region">Black Sea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_Anatolia_Region" title="Central Anatolia Region">Central</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Anatolia_Region" title="Eastern Anatolia Region">Eastern Anatolia</a> regions due to internal migration since the 1950s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[189]</a></sup> People registered in <a href="/wiki/Kastamonu_Province" title="Kastamonu Province">Kastamonu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ordu_Province" title="Ordu Province">Ordu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Giresun_Province" title="Giresun Province">Giresun</a>, <a href="/wiki/Erzurum_Province" title="Erzurum Province">Erzurum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samsun_Province" title="Samsun Province">Samsun</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malatya_Province" title="Malatya Province">Malatya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trabzon_Province" title="Trabzon Province">Trabzon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sinop_Province" title="Sinop Province">Sinop</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rize_Province" title="Rize Province">Rize</a> provinces represent the biggest population groups in Istanbul, meanwhile people registered in <a href="/wiki/Sivas" title="Sivas">Sivas</a> has the highest percentage with more than 760 thousand residents in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[190]</a></sup> A 2019 survey found that only 36% of the Istanbul's population was born in the province.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-:2-198">[191]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_and_religious_groups">Ethnic and religious groups</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Istanbul" title="Religion in Istanbul">Religion in Istanbul</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Assyrians_in_Turkey" title="Assyrians in Turkey">Assyrians in Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kurds_in_Istanbul" title="Kurds in Istanbul">Kurds in Istanbul</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bosniaks_in_Turkey" title="Bosniaks in Turkey">Bosniaks in Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greeks_in_Turkey" title="Greeks in Turkey">Greeks in Turkey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armenians_in_Turkey" title="Armenians in Turkey">Armenians in Turkey</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jews_in_Turkey" title="Jews in Turkey">Jews in Turkey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Albanians_in_Turkey" title="Albanians in Turkey">Albanians in Turkey</a></div>
<div class="barbox tleft" style="overflow-x: auto;">
<div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;">

</tr>

<td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;"><div style="background:turquoise; width:3%; overflow: hidden;">â</div></td>
