</tr>
</tbody></table>
</div>
</div>
<p>Istanbul has been a cosmopolitan city throughout much of its history, but it has become more homogenized since the end of the Ottoman era. The dominant ethnic group in the city is <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">Turkish people</a>, which also forms the majority group in Turkey. According to survey data 78% of the voting-age Turkish citizens in Istanbul state "Turkish" as their ethnic identity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_198-1"><a href="#cite_note-:2-198">[191]</a></sup>
</p><p>With estimates ranging from 2 to 4 million, <a href="/wiki/Kurds" title="Kurds">Kurds</a> form one of the largest ethnic minorities in Istanbul and are the biggest group after Turks among Turkish citizens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Karadaghi1995_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-Karadaghi1995-199">[192]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tirman1997_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tirman1997-200">[193]</a></sup> According to a 2019 <a href="/wiki/KONDA_Research_and_Consultancy" title="KONDA Research and Consultancy">KONDA</a> study, Kurds constituted around 17% of Istanbul's adult total population who were Turkish citizens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_198-2"><a href="#cite_note-:2-198">[191]</a></sup> Although the Kurdish presence in the city dates back to the early Ottoman period,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[194]</a></sup> the majority of Kurds in the city originate from villages in eastern and southeastern Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BaserToivanen2018_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-BaserToivanen2018-202">[195]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Zazas" title="Zazas">Zazas</a> are also present in the city and constitute around 1% of the total voting-age population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_198-3"><a href="#cite_note-:2-198">[191]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Arabs" title="Arabs">Arabs</a> form the city's other largest ethnic minority, with an estimated population of more than 2 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guardian2020_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-guardian2020-203">[196]</a></sup> Following Turkey's support for the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Spring" title="Arab Spring">Arab Spring</a>, Istanbul emerged as a hub for dissidents from across the <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">Arab world</a>, including former presidential candidates from Egypt, Kuwaiti MPs, and former ministers from Jordan, Saudi Arabia (including <a href="/wiki/Jamal_Khashoggi" title="Jamal Khashoggi">Jamal Khashoggi</a>), Syria, and Yemen.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-atlantic2013_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-atlantic2013-204">[197]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytarabs_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-nytarabs-205">[198]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-economist2018_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-economist2018-206">[199]</a></sup> The number of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Refugees_of_the_Syrian_Civil_War_in_Turkey" title="Refugees of the Syrian Civil War in Turkey">refugees of the Syrian Civil War in Turkey</a> residing in Istanbul is estimated to be around 1 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[200]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arabs_in_Turkey" title="Arabs in Turkey">Native Arab population in Turkey</a> who are Turkish citizens are found to be making up less than 1% of city's total adult population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_198-4"><a href="#cite_note-:2-198">[191]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:S%C3%BCleymaniye_Mosque_exterior_view.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/S%C3%BCleymaniye_Mosque_exterior_view.JPG/220px-S%C3%BCleymaniye_Mosque_exterior_view.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/S%C3%BCleymaniye_Mosque_exterior_view.JPG/330px-S%C3%BCleymaniye_Mosque_exterior_view.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/S%C3%BCleymaniye_Mosque_exterior_view.JPG/440px-S%C3%BCleymaniye_Mosque_exterior_view.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:S%C3%BCleymaniye_Mosque_exterior_view.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Built by <a href="/wiki/Suleiman_the_Magnificent" title="Suleiman the Magnificent">Suleiman the Magnificent</a>, the <a href="/wiki/S%C3%BCleymaniye_Mosque" title="SÃ¼leymaniye Mosque">SÃ¼leymaniye Mosque</a> (1550â1557) was designed by his chief architect <a href="/wiki/Mimar_Sinan" title="Mimar Sinan">Mimar Sinan</a>, the most illustrious of all <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_architecture" title="Ottoman architecture">Ottoman architects</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sinan-britannica_161-1"><a href="#cite_note-sinan-britannica-161">[155]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>2019 survey study by KONDA that examined the religiosity of the voting-age adults in Istanbul showed that 57% of the surveyed had a religion and were trying to practise its requirements. This was followed by nonobservant people with 26% who identified with a religion but generally did not practise its requirements. 11% stated they were fully devoted to their religion, meanwhile 6% were <a href="/wiki/Irreligion_in_Turkey" title="Irreligion in Turkey">non-believers</a> who did not believe the rules and requirements of a religion. 24% of the surveyed also identified themselves as "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Religious_conservatism" title="Religious conservatism">religious conservatives</a>". Around  90% of Istanbul's population are <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni Muslims</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alevism" title="Alevism">Alevism</a> forms the second biggest religious group.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_198-5"><a href="#cite_note-:2-198">[191]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[201]</a></sup>
</p><p>Into the 19th century, the Christians of Istanbul tended to be either <a href="/wiki/Greek_Orthodox_Church" title="Greek Orthodox Church">Greek Orthodox</a>, members of the <a href="/wiki/Armenian_Apostolic_Church" title="Armenian Apostolic Church">Armenian Apostolic Church</a> or Catholic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Levantines_(Latin_Christians)" title="Levantines (Latin Christians)">Levantines</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[202]</a></sup> Greeks and <a href="/wiki/Armenians_in_Istanbul" title="Armenians in Istanbul">Armenians</a> form the largest Christian population in the city. While Istanbul's Greek population was exempted from the 1923 population exchange with Greece, changes in tax status and the <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_pogrom" title="Istanbul pogrom">1955 anti-Greek pogrom</a> prompted thousands to leave.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-greek_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-greek-210">[203]</a></sup> Following <a href="/wiki/Greek_government-debt_crisis" title="Greek government-debt crisis">Greek migration to the city for work</a> in the 2010s, the Greek population rose to nearly 3,000 in 2019, still greatly diminished since 1919, when it stood at 350,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-greek_210-1"><a href="#cite_note-greek-210">[203]</a></sup> There are today 50,000 to 70,000 Armenians in Istanbul<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[204]</a></sup> down from a peak of 164,000 in 1913.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[205]</a></sup> As of 2019, an estimated 18,000 of the country's 25,000 Christian <a href="/wiki/Assyrian_people" title="Assyrian people">Assyrians</a> live in Istanbul.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[206]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_asv2021-11_img71_StAnthony_of_Padua_Church.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5147" data-file-width="4289" decoding="async" height="264" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Istanbul_asv2021-11_img71_StAnthony_of_Padua_Church.jpg/220px-Istanbul_asv2021-11_img71_StAnthony_of_Padua_Church.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Istanbul_asv2021-11_img71_StAnthony_of_Padua_Church.jpg/330px-Istanbul_asv2021-11_img71_StAnthony_of_Padua_Church.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Istanbul_asv2021-11_img71_StAnthony_of_Padua_Church.jpg/440px-Istanbul_asv2021-11_img71_StAnthony_of_Padua_Church.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_asv2021-11_img71_StAnthony_of_Padua_Church.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>There are 234 active churches in the city,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-heper2018_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-heper2018-214">[207]</a></sup> including the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_St._Anthony_of_Padua,_Istanbul" title="Church of St. Anthony of Padua, Istanbul">Church of St. Anthony of Padua</a> on <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0stiklal_Avenue" title="Ä°stiklal Avenue">Ä°stiklal Avenue</a>, in the district of <a href="/wiki/Beyo%C4%9Flu" title="BeyoÄlu">BeyoÄlu (Pera)</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The majority of the Catholic <i>Levantines</i> (Turkish: <i>Levanten</i>) in Istanbul and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Izmir" title="Izmir">Izmir</a> are the descendants of traders/colonists from the Italian <a href="/wiki/Maritime_republics" title="Maritime republics">maritime republics</a> of the Mediterranean (especially Genoa and <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">Venice</a>) and <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>, who obtained special rights and privileges called the <a href="/wiki/Capitulations_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Capitulations of the Ottoman Empire">Capitulations</a> from the Ottoman sultans in the 16th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[208]</a></sup> The community had more than 15,000 members during AtatÃ¼rk's presidency in the 1920s and 1930s, but today is reduced to only a few hundreds, according to Italo-Levantine writer <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Scognamillo" title="Giovanni Scognamillo">Giovanni Scognamillo</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[209]</a></sup> They continue to live in Istanbul (mostly in KarakÃ¶y, BeyoÄlu and <a href="/wiki/Ni%C5%9Fanta%C5%9F%C4%B1" title="NiÅantaÅÄ±">NiÅantaÅÄ±</a>), and Izmir (mostly in <a href="/wiki/Kar%C5%9F%C4%B1yaka" title="KarÅÄ±yaka">KarÅÄ±yaka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bornova" title="Bornova">Bornova</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buca" title="Buca">Buca</a>).
</p><p>Istanbul became one of the world's most important <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jewish" title="Jewish">Jewish</a> centers in the 16th and 17th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-epstein_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-epstein-217">[210]</a></sup> Romaniote and Ashkenazi communities existed in Istanbul before the conquest of Istanbul, but it was the arrival of Sephardic Jews that ushered a period of cultural flourishing. Sephardic Jews settled in the city after their expulsion from Spain and Portugal in 1492 and 1497.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-epstein_217-1"><a href="#cite_note-epstein-217">[210]</a></sup> Sympathetic to the plight of Sephardic Jews, <a href="/wiki/Bayezid_II" title="Bayezid II">Bayezid II</a> sent out the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Navy" title="Ottoman Navy">Ottoman Navy</a> under the command of admiral <a href="/wiki/Kemal_Reis" title="Kemal Reis">Kemal Reis</a> to Spain in 1492 in order to evacuate them safely to Ottoman lands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-epstein_217-2"><a href="#cite_note-epstein-217">[210]</a></sup> In marked contrast to <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Europe" title="History of the Jews in Europe">Jews in Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Europe" title="History of the Jews in Europe">Ottoman Jews</a> were allowed to work in any profession.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-makovetsky_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-makovetsky-218">[211]</a></sup> Ottoman Jews in Istanbul excelled in commerce, and came to particularly dominate the medical profession.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-makovetsky_218-1"><a href="#cite_note-makovetsky-218">[211]</a></sup> By 1711, using the printing press, books came to be published in <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Judaeo-Spanish" title="Judaeo-Spanish">Ladino</a>, Yiddish, and Hebrew.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nassigad_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-nassigad-219">[212]</a></sup> In large part due to emigration to Israel, the Jewish population in the city dropped from 100,000 in 1950<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-solomon_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-solomon-220">[213]</a></sup> to 15,000 in 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jewishvirtuallibrary_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-jewishvirtuallibrary-221">[214]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[215]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pop2021_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-pop2021-223">[216]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2>
<p>Politically, Istanbul is seen as the most important administrative region in Turkey. In the run-up to <a href="/wiki/2019_Turkish_local_elections" title="2019 Turkish local elections">local elections in 2019</a>, ErdoÄan claimed 'if we fail in Istanbul, we will fail in Turkey'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[217]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/March_2019_Istanbul_mayoral_election" title="March 2019 Istanbul mayoral election">contest in Istanbul</a> carried deep political, economic and symbolic significance for ErdoÄan, whose <a href="/wiki/1994_Istanbul_mayoral_election" title="1994 Istanbul mayoral election">election of mayor of Istanbul in 1994</a> had served as his launchpad.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-inglebylove_225-0"><a href="#cite_note-inglebylove-225">[218]</a></sup> For Ekrem Ä°mamoÄlu, winning the mayorlty of Istanbul was a huge moral victory, but for ErdoÄan it had practical ramifications: His party, AKP, lost control of the $4.8Â billion municipal budget, which had sustained patronage at the point of delivery of many public services for 25 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pitel2019_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-pitel2019-226">[219]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Imamoglu_press_conference_April_3,_2019.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1812" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="195" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Imamoglu_press_conference_April_3%2C_2019.jpg/220px-Imamoglu_press_conference_April_3%2C_2019.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Imamoglu_press_conference_April_3%2C_2019.jpg/330px-Imamoglu_press_conference_April_3%2C_2019.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Imamoglu_press_conference_April_3%2C_2019.jpg/440px-Imamoglu_press_conference_April_3%2C_2019.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Imamoglu_press_conference_April_3,_2019.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ekrem_%C4%B0mamo%C4%9Flu" title="Ekrem Ä°mamoÄlu">Ekrem Ä°mamoÄlu</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Republican_People%27s_Party_(Turkey)" title="Republican People's Party (Turkey)">CHP</a> is the 32nd and current <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mayor_of_Istanbul" title="Mayor of Istanbul">Mayor of Istanbul</a>, <a href="/wiki/June_2019_Istanbul_mayoral_election" title="June 2019 Istanbul mayoral election">elected in 2019</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>More recently, Istanbul and many of Turkey's metropolitan cities are following a trend away from the government and their right-wing ideology. In 2013 and 2014, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2013%E2%80%9314_protests_in_Turkey" title="2013â14 protests in Turkey">large-scale anti-AKP government protests</a> began in Ä°stanbul and spread throughout the nation. This trend first became evident electorally in the <a href="/wiki/2014_Istanbul_mayoral_election" title="2014 Istanbul mayoral election">2014 mayoral election</a> where the center-left opposition candidate won an impressive 40% of the vote, despite not winning. The first government defeat in Istanbul occurred in the <a href="/wiki/2017_Turkish_constitutional_referendum" title="2017 Turkish constitutional referendum">2017 constitutional referendum</a>, where Istanbul voted 'No' by 51.4% to 48.6%. The AKP government had supported a 'Yes' vote and won the vote nationally due to high support in rural parts of the country. The biggest defeat for the government came in the 2019 local elections, where their candidate for Mayor, former Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Binali_Y%C4%B1ld%C4%B1r%C4%B1m" title="Binali YÄ±ldÄ±rÄ±m">Binali YÄ±ldÄ±rÄ±m</a>, was defeated by a very narrow margin by the opposition candidate Ekrem Ä°mamoÄlu. Ä°mamoÄlu won the vote with 48.77% of the vote, against YÄ±ldÄ±rÄ±m's 48.61%, but the elections were controversially annulled by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Supreme_Electoral_Council_(Turkey)" title="Supreme Electoral Council (Turkey)">Supreme Electoral Council</a> due to AKP's claim of electoral fraud. In the re-run Ä°mamoÄlu gathered 54.22% of the total vote and widened the defeat margin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[220]</a></sup>
</p><p>Administratively, Istanbul is divided into 39 districts, more than any other <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Turkey" title="Provinces of Turkey">province</a> in Turkey. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_Province" title="Istanbul Province">Istanbul Province</a> sends 98 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Member_of_Parliament#Turkey" title="Member of Parliament">Members of Parliament</a> to the Grand National Assembly of Turkey, which has a total of 600 seats. For the purpose of parliamentary elections, Istanbul is divided into <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%B0stanbul_(electoral_districts)" title="Ä°stanbul (electoral districts)">three electoral districts</a>; two on the European side and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%B0stanbul_(1st_electoral_district)" title="Ä°stanbul (1st electoral district)">one on the Asian side</a>, electing 28, 35 and 35 MPs respectively.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Istanbul" title="Economy of Istanbul">Economy of Istanbul</a></div>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:758px"><div class="thumbinner"><div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_Skyline_Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F_%C5%9Ei%C5%9Fli.JPG" title="A view of DolmabahÃ§e Palace and the skyscrapers of Levent financial district in the background. Providing the only sea route to the Black Sea, the Bosporus is the world's busiest waterway that is used for international navigation."><img alt="" data-file-height="1307" data-file-width="4896" decoding="async" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Istanbul_Skyline_Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F_%C5%9Ei%C5%9Fli.JPG/750px-Istanbul_Skyline_Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F_%C5%9Ei%C5%9Fli.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Istanbul_Skyline_Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F_%C5%9Ei%C5%9Fli.JPG/1125px-Istanbul_Skyline_Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F_%C5%9Ei%C5%9Fli.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Istanbul_Skyline_Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F_%C5%9Ei%C5%9Fli.JPG/1500px-Istanbul_Skyline_Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F_%C5%9Ei%C5%9Fli.JPG 2x" width="750"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:center"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_Skyline_Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F_%C5%9Ei%C5%9Fli.JPG" title="File:Istanbul Skyline BeÅiktaÅ ÅiÅli.JPG"> </a></div>A view of <a href="/wiki/Dolmabah%C3%A7e_Palace" title="DolmabahÃ§e Palace">DolmabahÃ§e Palace</a> and the skyscrapers of <a href="/wiki/Levent" title="Levent">Levent</a> financial district in the background.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Istanbul-panoramic1_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-Istanbul-panoramic1-228">[221]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-levent-sporcular-park_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-levent-sporcular-park-229">[222]</a></sup> Providing the only sea route to the Black Sea, the Bosporus is the world's busiest waterway that is used for international navigation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hisdic_18-6"><a href="#cite_note-hisdic-18">[15]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:View_of_Levent_financial_district_from_Istanbul_Sapphire.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2106" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/View_of_Levent_financial_district_from_Istanbul_Sapphire.jpg/220px-View_of_Levent_financial_district_from_Istanbul_Sapphire.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/View_of_Levent_financial_district_from_Istanbul_Sapphire.jpg/330px-View_of_Levent_financial_district_from_Istanbul_Sapphire.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/View_of_Levent_financial_district_from_Istanbul_Sapphire.jpg/440px-View_of_Levent_financial_district_from_Istanbul_Sapphire.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:View_of_Levent_financial_district_from_Istanbul_Sapphire.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A view of <a href="/wiki/Levent" title="Levent">Levent</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Istanbul-panoramic1_228-1"><a href="#cite_note-Istanbul-panoramic1-228">[221]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-levent-sporcular-park_229-1"><a href="#cite_note-levent-sporcular-park-229">[222]</a></sup> financial district from <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Sapphire" title="Istanbul Sapphire">Istanbul Sapphire</a>. Levent, <a href="/wiki/Maslak" title="Maslak">Maslak</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Ei%C5%9Fli" title="ÅiÅli">ÅiÅli</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ata%C5%9Fehir" title="AtaÅehir">AtaÅehir</a> are the main business districts in the city.</div></div></div>
<p>Istanbul had the <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP" title="List of cities by GDP">eleventh-largest economy</a> among the world's urban areas in 2018, and is responsible for <span class="nowrap">30 percent</span> of Turkey's industrial output,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecd2020_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-oecd2020-230">[223]</a></sup> <span class="nowrap">31 percent</span> of GDP,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecd2020_230-1"><a href="#cite_note-oecd2020-230">[223]</a></sup> and <span class="nowrap">47 percent</span> of tax revenues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecd2020_230-2"><a href="#cite_note-oecd2020-230">[223]</a></sup>  The city's <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> adjusted by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">PPP</a> stood at <span class="nowrap">US$537.507 billion</span> in 2018,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[224]</a></sup> with manufacturing and services accounting for <span class="nowrap">36 percent</span> and <span class="nowrap">60 percent</span> of the economic output respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecd2020_230-3"><a href="#cite_note-oecd2020-230">[223]</a></sup> Istanbul's productivity is <span class="nowrap">110 percent</span> higher than the national average.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oecd2020_230-4"><a href="#cite_note-oecd2020-230">[223]</a></sup> Trade is economically important, accounting for <span class="nowrap">30 percent</span> of the economic output in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hisdic_18-7"><a href="#cite_note-hisdic-18">[15]</a></sup> In 2019, companies based in Istanbul produced exports worth <span class="nowrap">$83.66 billion</span> and received imports totaling <span class="nowrap">$128.34 billion</span>; these figures were equivalent to <span class="nowrap">47 percent</span> and <span class="nowrap">61 percent</span>, respectively, of the national totals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wbtrade_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-wbtrade-232">[225]</a></sup>
</p><p>Istanbul, which straddles the Bosporus strait, houses international ports that link Europe and Asia. The Bosporus, providing the only passage from the Black Sea to the Mediterranean, is the world's busiest and narrowest strait used for international navigation, with more than <span class="nowrap">200 million</span> tons of oil passing through it each year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOxford_Business_Group2009112_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOxford_Business_Group2009112-233">[226]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Montreux_Convention_Regarding_the_Regime_of_the_Straits" title="Montreux Convention Regarding the Regime of the Straits">International conventions</a> <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_navigation" title="Freedom of navigation">guarantee passage</a> between the Black and the Mediterranean seas,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-canalguardian_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-canalguardian-234">[227]</a></sup> even when tankers carry oil, <a href="/wiki/Liquefied_natural_gas" title="Liquefied natural gas">LNG</a>/<a href="/wiki/Liquefied_petroleum_gas" title="Liquefied petroleum gas">LPG</a>, chemicals, and other flammable or explosive materials as cargo. In 2011, as a workaround solution, the then Prime Minister ErdoÄan presented <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canal_Istanbul" title="Canal Istanbul">Canal Istanbul</a>, a project to open a new strait between the Black and Marmara seas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-canalguardian_234-1"><a href="#cite_note-canalguardian-234">[227]</a></sup> While the project was still on Turkey's agenda in 2020, there has not been a clear date set for it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hisdic_18-8"><a href="#cite_note-hisdic-18">[15]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:SirkeciBanks.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4032" data-file-width="3004" decoding="async" height="228" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/SirkeciBanks.jpg/170px-SirkeciBanks.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/SirkeciBanks.jpg/255px-SirkeciBanks.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/SirkeciBanks.jpg/340px-SirkeciBanks.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:SirkeciBanks.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Deutsche Orientbank AG (1906) in <a href="/wiki/Sirkeci" title="Sirkeci">Sirkeci</a></div></div></div>
<p>Shipping is a significant part of the city's economy, with <span class="nowrap">73.9 percent</span> of exports and <span class="nowrap">92.7 percent</span> of imports in 2018 executed by sea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hisdic_18-9"><a href="#cite_note-hisdic-18">[15]</a></sup> Istanbul has three major shipping ports â the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Haydarpa%C5%9Fa" title="Port of HaydarpaÅa">Port of HaydarpaÅa</a>, the Port of AmbarlÄ±, and the Port of Zeytinburnu â as well as several smaller ports and oil terminals along the Bosporus and the Sea of Marmara.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hisdic_18-10"><a href="#cite_note-hisdic-18">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>HaydarpaÅa, at the southeastern end of the Bosporus, was Istanbul's largest port until the early 2000s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lloyds_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-lloyds-235">[228]</a></sup> Since then operations were shifted to AmbarlÄ±, with plans to convert HaydarpaÅa into a tourism complex.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hisdic_18-11"><a href="#cite_note-hisdic-18">[15]</a></sup> In 2019, AmbarlÄ±, on the western edge of the urban center, had an annual capacity of 3,104,882 <a href="/wiki/Twenty-foot_equivalent_unit" title="Twenty-foot equivalent unit">TEUs</a>, making it the third-largest cargo terminal in the Mediterranean basin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lloyds_235-1"><a href="#cite_note-lloyds-235">[228]</a></sup>
</p><p>Istanbul has been an international banking hub since the 1980s,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hisdic_18-12"><a href="#cite_note-hisdic-18">[15]</a></sup> and is home to the only active <a href="/wiki/Exchange_(organized_market)" title="Exchange (organized market)">stock exchange</a> in Turkey, <a href="/wiki/Borsa_Istanbul" title="Borsa Istanbul">Borsa Istanbul</a>, which was originally established as the Ottoman Stock Exchange in 1866.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bnf_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-bnf-236">[229]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ottoman_Banks_Archives_and_Research_Centre.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1801" data-file-width="1447" decoding="async" height="212" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Ottoman_Banks_Archives_and_Research_Centre.jpg/170px-Ottoman_Banks_Archives_and_Research_Centre.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Ottoman_Banks_Archives_and_Research_Centre.jpg/255px-Ottoman_Banks_Archives_and_Research_Centre.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Ottoman_Banks_Archives_and_Research_Centre.jpg/340px-Ottoman_Banks_Archives_and_Research_Centre.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ottoman_Banks_Archives_and_Research_Centre.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ottoman Central Bank Head Office (1892) on <a href="/wiki/Bankalar_Caddesi" title="Bankalar Caddesi">Bankalar Caddesi</a></div></div></div>
<p>In 1995, keeping up with the financial trends, Borsa Istanbul moved its headquarters (which was originally located on <a href="/wiki/Bankalar_Caddesi" title="Bankalar Caddesi">Bankalar Caddesi</a>, the financial center of the Ottoman Empire,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bnf_236-1"><a href="#cite_note-bnf-236">[229]</a></sup> and later at the <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_4th_Vak%C4%B1f_Han" title="Istanbul 4th VakÄ±f Han">4th VakÄ±f Han</a> building in <a href="/wiki/Sirkeci" title="Sirkeci">Sirkeci</a>) to <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0stinye" title="Ä°stinye">Ä°stinye</a>, in the vicinity of Maslak, which hosts the headquarters of numerous Turkish banks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bist_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-bist-237">[230]</a></sup>
</p><p>By 2023, the AtaÅehir district on the Asian side of the city will host the new headquarters of a number of state-owned Turkish banks, including the <a href="/wiki/Central_Bank_of_the_Republic_of_Turkey" title="Central Bank of the Republic of Turkey">Central Bank of Turkey</a>, currently headquartered in Ankara.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloomberg2013_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bloomberg2013-238">[231]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[232]</a></sup>
</p><p><span class="nowrap">13.4 million</span> foreign tourists visited the city in 2018, making Istanbul the world's fifth most-visited city in that year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-statista.com_17-1"><a href="#cite_note-statista.com-17">[14]</a></sup> Istanbul and <a href="/wiki/Antalya" title="Antalya">Antalya</a> are Turkey's two largest international gateways, receiving a quarter of the nation's foreign tourists. Istanbul has more than fifty museums, with the TopkapÄ± Palace, the most visited museum in the city, bringing in more than <span class="nowrap">$30 million</span> in revenue each year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hisdic_18-13"><a href="#cite_note-hisdic-18">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>Istanbul expects 1 million tourists from cruise companies after the renovation of its cruise port, also known as <a href="/wiki/Galataport" title="Galataport">Galataport</a> in KarakÃ¶y district.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[233]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Istanbul" title="Culture of Istanbul">Culture of Istanbul</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Zarif_Mustafa_Pa%C5%9Fa_Yal%C4%B1s%C4%B1_in_Kanl%C4%B1ca_on_the_Bosphorus,_Turkey_001.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Zarif_Mustafa_Pa%C5%9Fa_Yal%C4%B1s%C4%B1_in_Kanl%C4%B1ca_on_the_Bosphorus%2C_Turkey_001.jpg/220px-Zarif_Mustafa_Pa%C5%9Fa_Yal%C4%B1s%C4%B1_in_Kanl%C4%B1ca_on_the_Bosphorus%2C_Turkey_001.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Zarif_Mustafa_Pa%C5%9Fa_Yal%C4%B1s%C4%B1_in_Kanl%C4%B1ca_on_the_Bosphorus%2C_Turkey_001.jpg/330px-Zarif_Mustafa_Pa%C5%9Fa_Yal%C4%B1s%C4%B1_in_Kanl%C4%B1ca_on_the_Bosphorus%2C_Turkey_001.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Zarif_Mustafa_Pa%C5%9Fa_Yal%C4%B1s%C4%B1_in_Kanl%C4%B1ca_on_the_Bosphorus%2C_Turkey_001.jpg/440px-Zarif_Mustafa_Pa%C5%9Fa_Yal%C4%B1s%C4%B1_in_Kanl%C4%B1ca_on_the_Bosphorus%2C_Turkey_001.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Zarif_Mustafa_Pa%C5%9Fa_Yal%C4%B1s%C4%B1_in_Kanl%C4%B1ca_on_the_Bosphorus,_Turkey_001.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Yal%C4%B1" title="YalÄ±">YalÄ±</a> houses on the <a href="/wiki/Bosporus" title="Bosporus">Bosporus</a> are among the frequently used settings in <a href="/wiki/Turkish_television_drama" title="Turkish television drama">Turkish television dramas (<i>dizi</i>)</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Istanbul was historically known as a cultural hub, but its cultural scene stagnated after the Turkish Republic shifted its focus toward Ankara.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[234]</a></sup> The new national government established programs that served to orient Turks toward musical traditions, especially those originating in Europe, but musical institutions and visits by foreign classical artists were primarily centered in the new capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[235]</a></sup>
</p><p>Much of Turkey's cultural scene had its roots in Istanbul, and by the 1980s and 1990s Istanbul reemerged globally as a city whose cultural significance is not solely based on its past glory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[236]</a></sup>
</p><p>By the end of the 19th century, Istanbul had established itself as a regional artistic center, with Turkish, European, and Middle Eastern artists flocking to the city. Despite efforts to make Ankara Turkey's cultural heart, Istanbul had the country's primary institution of art until the 1970s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gosotu2213_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-gosotu2213-244">[237]</a></sup> When additional universities and art journals were founded in Istanbul during the 1980s, artists formerly based in Ankara moved in.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[238]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbularcheology.jpg"><img alt="The faÃ§ade of a masonry building, with four Greek adorning its entrance, under a clear blue sky" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2268" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Istanbularcheology.jpg/220px-Istanbularcheology.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Istanbularcheology.jpg/330px-Istanbularcheology.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Istanbularcheology.jpg/440px-Istanbularcheology.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Istanbularcheology.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Archaeology_Museums" title="Istanbul Archaeology Museums">Istanbul Archaeology Museums</a>, founded by <a href="/wiki/Osman_Hamdi_Bey" title="Osman Hamdi Bey">Osman Hamdi Bey</a> in 1891, form Turkey's oldest modern museum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kultur_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-kultur-246">[239]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>BeyoÄlu has been transformed into the artistic center of the city, with young artists and older Turkish artists formerly residing abroad finding footing there. Modern art museums, including <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0stanbul_Modern" title="Ä°stanbul Modern">Ä°stanbul Modern</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pera_Museum" title="Pera Museum">Pera Museum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sak%C4%B1p_Sabanc%C4%B1_Museum" title="SakÄ±p SabancÄ± Museum">SakÄ±p SabancÄ± Museum</a> and <a href="/wiki/SantralIstanbul" title="SantralIstanbul">SantralIstanbul</a>, opened in the 2000s to complement the exhibition spaces and auction houses that have already contributed to the cosmopolitan nature of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[240]</a></sup> These museums have yet to attain the popularity of older museums on the historic peninsula, including the Istanbul Archaeology Museums, which ushered in the era of modern museums in Turkey, and the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_and_Islamic_Arts_Museum" title="Turkish and Islamic Arts Museum">Turkish and Islamic Arts Museum</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kultur_246-1"><a href="#cite_note-kultur-246">[239]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Restored_Paket_Postanesi_(Parcel_post_office)_is_now_a_symbol_of_Galataport.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2722" data-file-width="4014" decoding="async" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Restored_Paket_Postanesi_%28Parcel_post_office%29_is_now_a_symbol_of_Galataport.jpg/220px-Restored_Paket_Postanesi_%28Parcel_post_office%29_is_now_a_symbol_of_Galataport.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Restored_Paket_Postanesi_%28Parcel_post_office%29_is_now_a_symbol_of_Galataport.jpg/330px-Restored_Paket_Postanesi_%28Parcel_post_office%29_is_now_a_symbol_of_Galataport.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Restored_Paket_Postanesi_%28Parcel_post_office%29_is_now_a_symbol_of_Galataport.jpg/440px-Restored_Paket_Postanesi_%28Parcel_post_office%29_is_now_a_symbol_of_Galataport.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Restored_Paket_Postanesi_(Parcel_post_office)_is_now_a_symbol_of_Galataport.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Restored Paket Postanesi (Parcel post office) is now a symbol of <a href="/wiki/Galataport" title="Galataport">Galataport</a></div></div></div>
<p>The first film screening in Turkey was at YÄ±ldÄ±z Palace in 1896, a year after the technology publicly debuted in Paris.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[241]</a></sup> Movie theaters rapidly cropped up in BeyoÄlu, with the greatest concentration of theaters being along the street now known as Ä°stiklal Avenue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[242]</a></sup> Istanbul also became the heart of <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Turkey" title="Cinema of Turkey">Turkey's nascent film industry</a>, although Turkish films were not consistently developed until the 1950s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[243]</a></sup> Since then, Istanbul has been the most popular location to film Turkish dramas and comedies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[244]</a></sup> The Turkish film industry ramped up in the second half of the century, and with <i><a href="/wiki/Uzak" title="Uzak">Uzak</a></i> (2002) and <i><a href="/wiki/My_Father_and_My_Son" title="My Father and My Son">My Father and My Son</a></i> (2005), both filmed in Istanbul, the nation's movies began to see substantial international success.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[245]</a></sup> Istanbul and its picturesque skyline have also served as a backdrop for several foreign films, including <i><a href="/wiki/From_Russia_with_Love_(film)" title="From Russia with Love (film)">From Russia with Love</a></i> (1963), <i><a href="/wiki/Topkapi_(film)" title="Topkapi (film)">Topkapi</a></i> (1964), <i><a href="/wiki/The_World_Is_Not_Enough" title="The World Is Not Enough">The World Is Not Enough</a></i> (1999), and <i><a href="/wiki/Mission_Istaanbul" title="Mission Istaanbul">Mission Istaanbul</a></i> (2008).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[246]</a></sup>
</p><p>Coinciding with this cultural reemergence was the establishment of the Istanbul Festival, which began showcasing a variety of art from Turkey and around the world in 1973. From this flagship festival came the <a href="/wiki/International_Istanbul_Film_Festival" title="International Istanbul Film Festival">International Istanbul Film Festival</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_International_Jazz_Festival" title="Istanbul International Jazz Festival">Istanbul International Jazz Festival</a> in the early 1980s. With its focus now solely on music and dance, the Istanbul Festival has been known as the <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_International_Music_Festival" title="Istanbul International Music Festival">Istanbul International Music Festival</a> since 1994.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[247]</a></sup> The most prominent of the festivals that evolved from the original Istanbul Festival is the <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Biennial" title="Istanbul Biennial">Istanbul Biennial</a>, held every two years since 1987. Its early incarnations were aimed at showcasing Turkish visual art, and it has since opened to international artists and risen in prestige to join the elite <a href="/wiki/Biennale" title="Biennale">biennales</a>, alongside the <a href="/wiki/Venice_Biennale" title="Venice Biennale">Venice Biennale</a> and the <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo_Art_Biennial" title="SÃ£o Paulo Art Biennial">SÃ£o Paulo Art Biennial</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[248]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Leisure_and_entertainment">Leisure and entertainment</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Abdi_%C4%B0pek%C3%A7i_Street" title="Abdi Ä°pekÃ§i Street">Abdi Ä°pekÃ§i Street</a> in NiÅantaÅÄ±, <a href="/wiki/Galataport" title="Galataport">Galataport</a> Shopping Area in KarakÃ¶y and <a href="/wiki/Ba%C4%9Fdat_Avenue" title="BaÄdat Avenue">BaÄdat Avenue</a> on the Anatolian side of the city have evolved into high-end shopping districts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[249]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[250]</a></sup> Other focal points for shopping, leisure and entertainment include NiÅantaÅÄ±, OrtakÃ¶y, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bebek,_Istanbul" title="Bebek, Istanbul">Bebek</a>, and KadÄ±kÃ¶y.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[251]</a></sup> The city has <a href="/wiki/List_of_shopping_malls_in_Istanbul" title="List of shopping malls in Istanbul">numerous shopping centers</a>, from the historic to the modern. Istanbul also has an active <a href="/wiki/Nightlife" title="Nightlife">nightlife</a> and historic <a href="/wiki/Tavern" title="Tavern">taverns</a>, a signature characteristic of the city for centuries, if not millennia.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istiklal_str._Istanbul_-_panoramio.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1197" data-file-width="1800" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Istiklal_str._Istanbul_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-Istiklal_str._Istanbul_-_panoramio.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Istiklal_str._Istanbul_-_panoramio.jpg/330px-Istiklal_str._Istanbul_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Istiklal_str._Istanbul_-_panoramio.jpg/440px-Istiklal_str._Istanbul_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Istiklal_str._Istanbul_-_panoramio.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Around three million people visit <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0stiklal_Avenue" title="Ä°stiklal Avenue">Ä°stiklal Avenue</a> on weekend days</div></div></div>
<p>The Grand Bazaar, in operation since 1461, is among the world's oldest and largest covered markets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[252]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kos9192_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-kos9192-260">[253]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mahmutpasha_Bazaar,_Istanbul" title="Mahmutpasha Bazaar, Istanbul">Mahmutpasha Bazaar</a> is an open-air market extending between the Grand Bazaar and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spice_Bazaar,_Istanbul" title="Spice Bazaar, Istanbul">Egyptian Bazaar</a>, which has been Istanbul's major spice market since 1660.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Galleria_Atak%C3%B6y" title="Galleria AtakÃ¶y">Galleria AtakÃ¶y</a> ushered in the age of modern shopping malls in Turkey when it opened in 1987.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[254]</a></sup> Since then, malls have become major shopping centers outside the historic peninsula. <a href="/wiki/Akmerkez" title="Akmerkez">Akmerkez</a> was awarded the titles of "Europe's best" and "World's best" shopping mall by the <a href="/wiki/International_Council_of_Shopping_Centers" title="International Council of Shopping Centers">International Council of Shopping Centers</a> in 1995 and 1996; <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Cevahir" title="Istanbul Cevahir">Istanbul Cevahir</a> has been one of the continent's largest since opening in 2005; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kanyon_Shopping_Mall,_Istanbul" title="Kanyon Shopping Mall, Istanbul">Kanyon</a> won the Cityscape Architectural Review Award in the Commercial Built category in 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kos9192_260-1"><a href="#cite_note-kos9192-260">[253]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/%C4%B0stinye_Park" title="Ä°stinye Park">Ä°stinye Park</a> in Ä°stinye and <a href="/wiki/Zorlu_Center" title="Zorlu Center">Zorlu Center</a> near Levent are among the newest malls which include the stores of the world's top fashion brands.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul,_Turkey.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2861" data-file-width="3951" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg/220px-S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg/330px-S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg/440px-S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul%2C_Turkey.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House_in_Istanbul,_Turkey.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/S%C3%BCreyya_Opera_House" title="SÃ¼reyya Opera House">SÃ¼reyya Opera House</a></div></div></div>
<p>Along Ä°stiklal Avenue is the <a href="/wiki/%C3%87i%C3%A7ek_Pasaj%C4%B1" title="ÃiÃ§ek PasajÄ±">ÃiÃ§ek PasajÄ±</a> (Flower Passage), a 19th-century shopping gallery which is today home to winehouses (known as <i>meyhanes</i>), pubs and restaurants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[255]</a></sup> Ä°stiklal Avenue, originally known for its taverns, has shifted toward shopping, but the nearby Nevizade Street is still lined with winehouses and pubs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[256]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[257]</a></sup> Some other neighborhoods around Ä°stiklal Avenue have been revamped to cater to BeyoÄlu's nightlife, with formerly commercial streets now lined with pubs, cafes, and restaurants playing live music.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[258]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:EAA_Zorlu_Center.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="944" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/EAA_Zorlu_Center.jpg/220px-EAA_Zorlu_Center.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/EAA_Zorlu_Center.jpg/330px-EAA_Zorlu_Center.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/EAA_Zorlu_Center.jpg/440px-EAA_Zorlu_Center.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:EAA_Zorlu_Center.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Zorlu_Center" title="Zorlu Center">Zorlu Center</a>, designed by <a href="/wiki/Emre_Arolat" title="Emre Arolat">EAA</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tabanl%C4%B1o%C4%9Flu_Architects" title="TabanlÄ±oÄlu Architects">TabanlÄ±oÄlu Architects</a></div></div></div>
<p>Istanbul is known for its historic <a href="/wiki/Seafood" title="Seafood">seafood</a> restaurants. Many of the city's most popular and upscale seafood restaurants line the shores of the Bosphorus (particularly in neighborhoods like OrtakÃ¶y, Bebek, <a href="/wiki/Arnavutk%C3%B6y" title="ArnavutkÃ¶y">ArnavutkÃ¶y</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yenik%C3%B6y,_Istanbul" title="YenikÃ¶y, Istanbul">YenikÃ¶y</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beylerbeyi" title="Beylerbeyi">Beylerbeyi</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C3%87engelk%C3%B6y" title="ÃengelkÃ¶y">ÃengelkÃ¶y</a>). <a href="/wiki/Kumkap%C4%B1" title="KumkapÄ±">KumkapÄ±</a> along the Sea of Marmara has a pedestrian zone that hosts around fifty fish restaurants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[259]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Princes%27_Islands" title="Princes' Islands">Princes' Islands</a>, 15 kilometers (9Â mi) from the city center, are also popular for their seafood restaurants. Because of their restaurants, historic summer mansions, and tranquil, car-free streets, the Prince Islands are a popular vacation destination among Istanbulites and foreign tourists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[260]</a></sup>
</p><p>Istanbul is also famous for its sophisticated and elaborately-cooked dishes of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_cuisine" title="Ottoman cuisine">Ottoman cuisine</a>. Following the influx of immigrants from southeastern and eastern Turkey, which began in the 1960s, the city's foodscape has drastically changed by the end of the century; with influences of Middle Eastern cuisine such as <a href="/wiki/Kebab" title="Kebab">kebab</a> taking an important place in the food scene.
</p><p>Restaurants featuring foreign cuisines are mainly concentrated in the BeyoÄlu, BeÅiktaÅ, <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Ei%C5%9Fli" title="ÅiÅli">ÅiÅli</a> and KadÄ±kÃ¶y districts.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Pride" title="Istanbul Pride">Istanbul Pride</a> is held for the first time in 2003. Turkey became the first Muslim-majority country to held a gay pride march. It was also the first gay pride in <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a> and <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[261]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_sport_facilities_in_Istanbul" title="List of sport facilities in Istanbul">List of sport facilities in Istanbul</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Sukrusaracoglu.jpg/400px-Sukrusaracoglu.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle"
