srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Vodafone_Park_Panorama.jpg/300px-Vodafone_Park_Panorama.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Vodafone_Park_Panorama.jpg/400px-Vodafone_Park_Panorama.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption"><div><ol><li><a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk_Olympic_Stadium" title="AtatÃ¼rk Olympic Stadium">AtatÃ¼rk Olympic Stadium</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Nef_Stadium" title="Nef Stadium">Nef Stadium</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/%C5%9E%C3%BCkr%C3%BC_Saraco%C4%9Flu_Stadium" title="ÅÃ¼krÃ¼ SaracoÄlu Stadium">ÅÃ¼krÃ¼ SaracoÄlu Stadium</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Vodafone_Park" title="Vodafone Park">Vodafone Park</a></li></ol></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Istanbul is home to some of Turkey's oldest <a href="/wiki/Sports_club" title="Sports club">sports clubs</a>. <a href="/wiki/Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F_J.K." title="BeÅiktaÅ J.K.">BeÅiktaÅ JK</a>, established in 1903, is considered the oldest of these sports clubs. Due to its initial status as Turkey's only club, BeÅiktaÅ occasionally represented the Ottoman Empire and Turkish Republic in international sports competitions, earning the right to place the Turkish flag inside its team logo.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fifa-bes_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-fifa-bes-269">[262]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Galatasaray_S.K." title="Galatasaray S.K.">Galatasaray SK</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_S.K." title="FenerbahÃ§e S.K.">FenerbahÃ§e SK</a> have fared better in international competitions and have won more <a href="/wiki/S%C3%BCper_Lig" title="SÃ¼per Lig">SÃ¼per Lig</a> titles, at 22 and 19 times, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[263]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fifa-gal_271-0"><a href="#cite_note-fifa-gal-271">[264]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[265]</a></sup> Galatasaray and FenerbahÃ§e have a long-standing rivalry, with Galatasaray based in the European part and FenerbahÃ§e based in the Anatolian part of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fifa-gal_271-1"><a href="#cite_note-fifa-gal-271">[264]</a></sup> Istanbul has seven basketball teamsâ<a href="/wiki/Anadolu_Efes_S.K." title="Anadolu Efes S.K.">Anadolu Efes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Be%C5%9Fikta%C5%9F_J.K._(men%27s_basketball)" title="BeÅiktaÅ J.K. (men's basketball)">BeÅiktaÅ</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dar%C3%BC%C5%9F%C5%9Fafaka_S.K." title="DarÃ¼ÅÅafaka S.K.">DarÃ¼ÅÅafaka</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_Men%27s_Basketball" title="FenerbahÃ§e Men's Basketball">FenerbahÃ§e</a>, <a href="/wiki/Galatasaray_S.K._(men%27s_basketball)" title="Galatasaray S.K. (men's basketball)">Galatasaray</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C4%B0stanbul_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk%C5%9Fehir_Belediyespor_(basketball)" title="Ä°stanbul BÃ¼yÃ¼kÅehir Belediyespor (basketball)">Ä°stanbul BÃ¼yÃ¼kÅehir Belediyespor</a> and <a href="/wiki/B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk%C3%A7ekmece_Basketbol" title="BÃ¼yÃ¼kÃ§ekmece Basketbol">BÃ¼yÃ¼kÃ§ekmece</a>âthat play in the premier-level <a href="/wiki/Basketbol_S%C3%BCper_Ligi" title="Basketbol SÃ¼per Ligi">Turkish Basketball Super League</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[266]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many of Istanbul's sports facilities have been built or upgraded since 2000 to bolster the city's bids for the <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games" title="Summer Olympic Games">Summer Olympic Games</a>. <a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk_Olympic_Stadium" title="AtatÃ¼rk Olympic Stadium">AtatÃ¼rk Olympic Stadium</a>, the largest multi-purpose stadium in Turkey, was completed in 2002 as an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_Association_of_Athletics_Federations" title="International Association of Athletics Federations">IAAF</a> first-class venue for <a href="/wiki/Track_and_field" title="Track and field">track and field</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[267]</a></sup> The stadium hosted the <a href="/wiki/2005_UEFA_Champions_League_Final" title="2005 UEFA Champions League Final">2005 UEFA Champions League Final</a>, and was selected by the <a href="/wiki/UEFA" title="UEFA">UEFA</a> to host the CL Final games of <a href="/wiki/2020_UEFA_Champions_League_Final" title="2020 UEFA Champions League Final">2020</a> and <a href="/wiki/2021_UEFA_Champions_League_Final" title="2021 UEFA Champions League Final">2021</a>, which were relocated to <a href="/wiki/Lisbon" title="Lisbon">Lisbon</a> (2020) and <a href="/wiki/Porto" title="Porto">Porto</a> (2021) due to the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[268]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/%C5%9E%C3%BCkr%C3%BC_Saraco%C4%9Flu_Stadium" title="ÅÃ¼krÃ¼ SaracoÄlu Stadium">ÅÃ¼krÃ¼ SaracoÄlu Stadium</a>, FenerbahÃ§e's home field, hosted the <a href="/wiki/2009_UEFA_Cup_Final" title="2009 UEFA Cup Final">2009 UEFA Cup Final</a> three years after its completion. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrk_Telekom_Arena" title="TÃ¼rk Telekom Arena">TÃ¼rk Telekom Arena</a> opened in 2011 to replace <a href="/wiki/Ali_Sami_Yen_Stadium" title="Ali Sami Yen Stadium">Ali Sami Yen Stadium</a> as Galatasaray's home turf,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[269]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[270]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Vodafone_Park" title="Vodafone Park">Vodafone Park</a>, opened in 2016 to replace <a href="/wiki/BJK_%C4%B0n%C3%B6n%C3%BC_Stadium" title="BJK Ä°nÃ¶nÃ¼ Stadium">BJK Ä°nÃ¶nÃ¼ Stadium</a> as the home turf of BeÅiktaÅ, hosted the <a href="/wiki/2019_UEFA_Super_Cup" title="2019 UEFA Super Cup">2019 UEFA Super Cup</a> game. All four stadiums are elite <a href="/wiki/UEFA_stadium_categories" title="UEFA stadium categories">Category 4</a> (formerly five-star) UEFA stadiums.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uefa-category_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-uefa-category-281">[h]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Sinan_Erdem_Dome" title="Sinan Erdem Dome">Sinan Erdem Dome</a>, among the largest indoor arenas in Europe, hosted the final of the <a href="/wiki/2010_FIBA_World_Championship" title="2010 FIBA World Championship">2010 FIBA World Championship</a>, the <a href="/wiki/2012_IAAF_World_Indoor_Championships" title="2012 IAAF World Indoor Championships">2012 IAAF World Indoor Championships</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_Euroleague" title="2011â12 Euroleague">2011â12 Euroleague</a> and <a href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_EuroLeague" title="2016â17 EuroLeague">2016â17 EuroLeague</a> Final Fours.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[274]</a></sup> Prior to the completion of the Sinan Erdem Dome in 2010, <a href="/wiki/Abdi_%C4%B0pek%C3%A7i_Arena" title="Abdi Ä°pekÃ§i Arena">Abdi Ä°pekÃ§i Arena</a> was Istanbul's primary indoor arena, having hosted the finals of <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_2001" title="EuroBasket 2001">EuroBasket 2001</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[275]</a></sup> Several other indoor arenas, including the <a href="/wiki/BJK_Akatlar_Arena" title="BJK Akatlar Arena">BeÅiktaÅ Akatlar Arena</a>, have also been inaugurated since 2000, serving as the home courts of Istanbul's sports clubs. The most recent of these is the 13,800-seat <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%9Clker_Sports_Arena" title="Ãlker Sports Arena">Ãlker Sports Arena</a>, which opened in 2012 as the home court of FenerbahÃ§e's basketball teams.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[276]</a></sup> Despite the construction boom, five bids for the Summer Olympicsâin <a href="/wiki/2000_Summer_Olympics" title="2000 Summer Olympics">2000</a>, <a href="/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics" title="2004 Summer Olympics">2004</a>, <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008</a>, <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012</a>, and <a href="/wiki/2020_Summer_Olympics" title="2020 Summer Olympics">2020</a>âand national bids for <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012" title="UEFA Euro 2012">UEFA Euro 2012</a> and <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016" title="UEFA Euro 2016">UEFA Euro 2016</a> have ended unsuccessfully.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[277]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/TVF_Burhan_Felek_Sport_Hall" title="TVF Burhan Felek Sport Hall">TVF Burhan Felek Sport Hall</a> is one of the major volleyball arenas in the city and hosts clubs such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eczac%C4%B1ba%C5%9F%C4%B1_VitrA" title="EczacÄ±baÅÄ± VitrA">EczacÄ±baÅÄ± VitrA</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vak%C4%B1fbank_S.K." title="VakÄ±fbank S.K.">VakÄ±fbank SK</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fenerbah%C3%A7e_Women%27s_Volleyball" title="FenerbahÃ§e Women's Volleyball">FenerbahÃ§e</a> who have won numerous <a href="/wiki/CEV_Women%27s_Champions_League" title="CEV Women's Champions League">European</a> and <a href="/wiki/FIVB_Volleyball_Women%27s_Club_World_Championship" title="FIVB Volleyball Women's Club World Championship">World Championship</a> titles.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Between the 2005â2011 seasons,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[278]</a></sup> and in the 2020 season,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[279]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Park" title="Istanbul Park">Istanbul Park</a> racing circuit hosted the <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula One</a> <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Grand_Prix" title="Turkish Grand Prix">Turkish Grand Prix</a>. The 2021 F1 Turkish Grand Prix was initially cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[280]</a></sup> but on 25 June 2021, it was announced that the 2021 F1 Turkish Grand Prix will take place on 3 October 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[281]</a></sup> Istanbul Park was also a venue of the <a href="/wiki/World_Touring_Car_Championship" title="World Touring Car Championship">World Touring Car Championship</a> and the <a href="/wiki/European_Le_Mans_Series" title="European Le Mans Series">European Le Mans Series</a> in 2005 and 2006, but the track has not seen either of these competitions since then.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[282]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[283]</a></sup> It also hosted the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Motorcycle_Grand_Prix" title="Turkish Motorcycle Grand Prix">Turkish Motorcycle Grand Prix</a> between 2005 and 2007. Istanbul was occasionally a venue of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/F1_Powerboat_World_Championship" title="F1 Powerboat World Championship">F1 Powerboat World Championship</a>, with the last race on the Bosphorus strait on 12â13 August 2000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[284]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Reliable sources"><span title="The material near this tag may rely on an unreliable source. (December 2020)">unreliable source?</span></a></i>]</sup> The last race of the <a href="/wiki/Offshore_powerboat_racing#UIM_Powerboat_GPS_World_Championship" title="Offshore powerboat racing">Powerboat P1 World Championship</a> on the Bosphorus took place on 19â21 June 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[285]</a></sup> Istanbul Sailing Club, established in 1952, hosts races and other sailing events on the waterways in and around Istanbul each year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[286]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[287]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:TV_tower,_Istanbul_(_1100239).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3520" data-file-width="2347" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/TV_tower%2C_Istanbul_%28_1100239%29.jpg/170px-TV_tower%2C_Istanbul_%28_1100239%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/TV_tower%2C_Istanbul_%28_1100239%29.jpg/255px-TV_tower%2C_Istanbul_%28_1100239%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/TV_tower%2C_Istanbul_%28_1100239%29.jpg/340px-TV_tower%2C_Istanbul_%28_1100239%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:TV_tower,_Istanbul_(_1100239).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/K%C3%BC%C3%A7%C3%BCk_%C3%87aml%C4%B1ca_TV_Radio_Tower" title="KÃ¼Ã§Ã¼k ÃamlÄ±ca TV Radio Tower">KÃ¼Ã§Ã¼k ÃamlÄ±ca TV Radio Tower</a> (369Â m (1,211Â ft)) is the tallest structure in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[288]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Most state-run radio and television stations are based in Ankara, but Istanbul is the primary hub of Turkish media. The industry has its roots in the former Ottoman capital, where the first Turkish newspaper, <i>Takvim-i Vekayi</i> (Calendar of Affairs), was published in 1831. The <a href="/wiki/Ca%C4%9Falo%C4%9Flu" title="CaÄaloÄlu">CaÄaloÄlu</a> street on which the newspaper was printed, BÃ¢b-Ä± Ãli Street, rapidly became the center of Turkish print media, alongside BeyoÄlu across the Golden Horn.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[289]</a></sup>
</p><p>Istanbul now has a wide variety of periodicals. Most nationwide newspapers are based in Istanbul, with simultaneous Ankara and Ä°zmir editions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-loc-pro_298-0"><a href="#cite_note-loc-pro-298">[290]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/H%C3%BCrriyet" title="HÃ¼rriyet">HÃ¼rriyet</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Sabah_(newspaper)" title="Sabah (newspaper)">Sabah</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Posta_(newspaper)" title="Posta (newspaper)">Posta</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/S%C3%B6zc%C3%BC" title="SÃ¶zcÃ¼">SÃ¶zcÃ¼</a></i>, the country's top four papers, are all headquartered in Istanbul, boasting more than 275,000 weekly sales each.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[291]</a></sup> <i>HÃ¼rriyet</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span>s English-language edition, <i><a href="/wiki/H%C3%BCrriyet_Daily_News" title="HÃ¼rriyet Daily News">HÃ¼rriyet Daily News</a></i>, has been printed since 1961, but the English-language <i><a href="/wiki/Daily_Sabah" title="Daily Sabah">Daily Sabah</a></i>, first published by <i>Sabah</i> in 2014, has overtaken it in circulation. Several smaller newspapers, including popular publications like <i><a href="/wiki/Cumhuriyet" title="Cumhuriyet">Cumhuriyet</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Milliyet" title="Milliyet">Milliyet</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Habert%C3%BCrk" title="HabertÃ¼rk">HabertÃ¼rk</a></i> are also based in Istanbul.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-loc-pro_298-1"><a href="#cite_note-loc-pro-298">[290]</a></sup> Istanbul also has long-running <a href="/wiki/Armenian_language" title="Armenian language">Armenian language</a> newspapers, notably the dailies <i><a href="/wiki/Marmara_(newspaper)" title="Marmara (newspaper)">Marmara</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Jamanak" title="Jamanak">Jamanak</a></i> and the bilingual weekly <i><a href="/wiki/Agos" title="Agos">Agos</a></i> in Armenian and Turkish.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Radio broadcasts in Istanbul date back to 1927, when Turkey's first radio transmission came from atop the Central Post Office in EminÃ¶nÃ¼. Control of this transmission, and other radio stations established in the following decades, ultimately came under the state-run <a href="/wiki/Turkish_Radio_and_Television_Corporation" title="Turkish Radio and Television Corporation">Turkish Radio and Television Corporation</a> (TRT), which held a monopoly on radio and television broadcasts between its founding in 1964 and 1990.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-trt-radio_300-0"><a href="#cite_note-trt-radio-300">[292]</a></sup> Today, TRT runs four national radio stations; these stations have transmitters across the country so each can reach over <span class="nowrap">90 percent</span> of the country's population, but only <span class="nowrap">Radio 2</span> is based in Istanbul. Offering a range of content from educational programming to coverage of sporting events, <span class="nowrap">Radio 2</span> is the most popular radio station in Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-trt-radio_300-1"><a href="#cite_note-trt-radio-300">[292]</a></sup> Istanbul's airwaves are the busiest in Turkey, primarily featuring either Turkish-language or English-language content. One of the exceptions, offering both, is <a href="/wiki/A%C3%A7%C4%B1k_Radyo" title="AÃ§Ä±k Radyo">AÃ§Ä±k Radyo</a> (94.9 FM). Among Turkey's first private stations, and the first featuring foreign popular music, was Istanbul's <a href="/wiki/Metro_FM_(Turkey)" title="Metro FM (Turkey)">Metro FM</a> (97.2 FM). The state-run <span class="nowrap">Radio 3</span>, although based in Ankara, also features English-language popular music, and English-language news programming is provided on NTV Radyo (102.8 FM).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[293]</a></sup>
</p><p>TRT-Children is the only TRT television station based in Istanbul.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[294]</a></sup> Istanbul is home to the headquarters of several Turkish stations and regional headquarters of international media outlets. Istanbul-based <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Star_TV_(Turkey)" title="Star TV (Turkey)">Star TV</a> was the first private television network to be established following the end of the TRT monopoly; Star TV and <a href="/wiki/Show_TV" title="Show TV">Show TV</a> (also based in Istanbul) remain highly popular throughout the country, airing Turkish and American series.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[295]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kanal_D" title="Kanal D">Kanal D</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atv_(Turkey)" title="Atv (Turkey)">ATV</a> are other stations in Istanbul that offer a mix of news and series; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NTV_(Turkey)" title="NTV (Turkey)">NTV</a> (partnered with U.S. media outlet <a href="/wiki/MSNBC" title="MSNBC">MSNBC</a>) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sky_Turk_360" title="Sky Turk 360">Sky Turk</a>âboth based in the cityâare mainly just known for their news coverage in Turkish. The <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a> has a regional office in Istanbul, assisting its Turkish-language news operations, and the American news channel <a href="/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a> established the Turkish-language <a href="/wiki/CNN_T%C3%BCrk" title="CNN TÃ¼rk">CNN TÃ¼rk</a> there in 1999.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[296]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Turkey" title="Education in Turkey">Education in Turkey</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:IstanUni.jpg"><img alt="A triumphal arch adjacent to a Turkish flag and in front of an open plaza" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3024" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/IstanUni.jpg/220px-IstanUni.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/IstanUni.jpg/330px-IstanUni.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/IstanUni.jpg/440px-IstanUni.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:IstanUni.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Main entrance gate of <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_University" title="Istanbul University">Istanbul University</a>, the city's oldest Turkish institution, established in 1453.</div></div></div>
<p>In 2015, more than 57,000 students attended <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_schools_in_Istanbul" title="List of schools in Istanbul">7,934 schools</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-educationheper_305-0"><a href="#cite_note-educationheper-305">[297]</a></sup> including the renowned <a href="/wiki/Galatasaray_High_School" title="Galatasaray High School">Galatasaray High School</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kabata%C5%9F_Erkek_Lisesi" title="KabataÅ Erkek Lisesi">KabataÅ Erkek Lisesi</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_Lisesi" title="Istanbul Lisesi">Istanbul Lisesi</a>. Galatasaray High School was established in 1481 and is the oldest public high school in Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-educationheper_305-1"><a href="#cite_note-educationheper-305">[297]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some of the most renowned and highly ranked universities in Turkey are in Istanbul. <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_University" title="Istanbul University">Istanbul University</a>, the nation's oldest institute of higher education, dates back to 1453 and its dental, law, medical schools were founded in the 19th century.
</p><p>Istanbul has more than 93 colleges and universities,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-educationheper_305-2"><a href="#cite_note-educationheper-305">[297]</a></sup> with 400,000 students<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ieft_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-ieft-306">[298]</a></sup> enrolled in 2016. The city's largest private universities include <a href="/wiki/Sabanc%C4%B1_University" title="SabancÄ± University">SabancÄ± University</a>, with its main campus in <a href="/wiki/Tuzla,_Istanbul" title="Tuzla, Istanbul">Tuzla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ko%C3%A7_University" title="KoÃ§ University">KoÃ§ University</a> in SarÄ±yer, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C3%96zye%C4%9Fin_%C3%9Cniversitesi" title="ÃzyeÄin Ãniversitesi">ÃzyeÄin Ãniversitesi</a> near <a href="/wiki/Altunizade" title="Altunizade">Altunizade</a>. Istanbul's first private university, KoÃ§ University, was founded as late as 1992, because private universities were not allowed in Turkey before the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Turkey" title="Constitution of Turkey">1982 amendment</a> to the constitution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-educationheper_305-3"><a href="#cite_note-educationheper-305">[297]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:428px;max-width:428px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:182px;max-width:182px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_asv2020-02_img69_Ma%C3%A7ka_Armory.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="4348" data-file-width="5218" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Istanbul_asv2020-02_img69_Ma%C3%A7ka_Armory.jpg/180px-Istanbul_asv2020-02_img69_Ma%C3%A7ka_Armory.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Istanbul_asv2020-02_img69_Ma%C3%A7ka_Armory.jpg/270px-Istanbul_asv2020-02_img69_Ma%C3%A7ka_Armory.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Istanbul_asv2020-02_img69_Ma%C3%A7ka_Armory.jpg/360px-Istanbul_asv2020-02_img69_Ma%C3%A7ka_Armory.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:242px;max-width:242px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_asv2021-10_img09_Ta%C5%9Fk%C4%B1%C5%9Fla.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3656" data-file-width="5849" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Istanbul_asv2021-10_img09_Ta%C5%9Fk%C4%B1%C5%9Fla.jpg/240px-Istanbul_asv2021-10_img09_Ta%C5%9Fk%C4%B1%C5%9Fla.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Istanbul_asv2021-10_img09_Ta%C5%9Fk%C4%B1%C5%9Fla.jpg/360px-Istanbul_asv2021-10_img09_Ta%C5%9Fk%C4%B1%C5%9Fla.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Istanbul_asv2021-10_img09_Ta%C5%9Fk%C4%B1%C5%9Fla.jpg/480px-Istanbul_asv2021-10_img09_Ta%C5%9Fk%C4%B1%C5%9Fla.jpg 2x" width="240"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Ma%C3%A7ka,_%C4%B0stanbul" title="MaÃ§ka, Ä°stanbul">MaÃ§ka</a> (left) and TaÅkÄ±Åla (right) campuses of <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Technical_University" title="Istanbul Technical University">Istanbul Technical University</a></div></div></div></div>
<p>Public universities with a major presence in the city, such as Istanbul University, <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Technical_University" title="Istanbul Technical University">Istanbul Technical University</a> (the world's third-oldest university dedicated entirely to engineering, established in 1773), and <a href="/wiki/Bo%C4%9Fazi%C3%A7i_University" title="BoÄaziÃ§i University">BoÄaziÃ§i University</a> (formerly the higher education section of <a href="/wiki/Robert_College" title="Robert College">Robert College</a> until 1971) provide education in <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> as the primary foreign language, while the primary foreign language of education at <a href="/wiki/Galatasaray_University" title="Galatasaray University">Galatasaray University</a> is <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a> (as is the case at Galatasaray High School).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-educationheper_305-4"><a href="#cite_note-educationheper-305">[297]</a></sup>
</p><p>Istanbul is also home to several conservatories and art schools, including <a href="/wiki/Mimar_Sinan_Fine_Arts_University" title="Mimar Sinan Fine Arts University">Mimar Sinan Academy of Fine Arts</a>, founded in 1882.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-finearts_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-finearts-307">[299]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_services">Public services</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Utilities_in_Istanbul" title="Utilities in Istanbul">Utilities in Istanbul</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Turkey" title="Telecommunications in Turkey">Telecommunications in Turkey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_Turkey" title="Health care in Turkey">Health care in Turkey</a></div>
<p>Istanbul's first <a href="/wiki/Water_supply" title="Water supply">water supply</a> systems date back to the city's early history, when <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aqueduct_(watercourse)" title="Aqueduct (watercourse)">aqueducts</a> (such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Valens_Aqueduct" title="Valens Aqueduct">Valens Aqueduct</a>) deposited the water in the city's numerous <a href="/wiki/Cistern" title="Cistern">cisterns</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iskitarihce_308-0"><a href="#cite_note-iskitarihce-308">[300]</a></sup> At the behest of Suleiman the Magnificent, the KÄ±rkÃ§eÅme water supply network was constructed; by 1563, the network provided 4,200 cubic meters (150,000Â cuÂ ft) of water to <span class="nowrap">158 sites</span> each day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iskitarihce_308-1"><a href="#cite_note-iskitarihce-308">[300]</a></sup> In later years, in response to increasing public demand, water from various springs was channeled to public fountains, like the <a href="/wiki/Fountain_of_Ahmed_III" title="Fountain of Ahmed III">Fountain of Ahmed III</a>, by means of supply lines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[301]</a></sup> Today, Istanbul has a chlorinated and filtered water supply and a <a href="/wiki/Sewage_treatment" title="Sewage treatment">sewage treatment</a> system managed by the Istanbul Water and Sewerage Administration (Ä°stanbul Su ve Kanalizasyon Ä°daresi, Ä°SKÄ°).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[302]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sunset_at_Santral_Istanbul.jpg"><img alt="A brick factory stands in front of a park, with open green space, a reflecting pool, and benches" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2088" data-file-width="3336" decoding="async" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Sunset_at_Santral_Istanbul.jpg/220px-Sunset_at_Santral_Istanbul.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Sunset_at_Santral_Istanbul.jpg/330px-Sunset_at_Santral_Istanbul.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Sunset_at_Santral_Istanbul.jpg/440px-Sunset_at_Santral_Istanbul.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sunset_at_Santral_Istanbul.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Silahtara%C4%9Fa_Power_Station" title="SilahtaraÄa Power Station">SilahtaraÄa Power Station</a>, now the art museum <a href="/wiki/SantralIstanbul" title="SantralIstanbul">SantralIstanbul</a>, was Istanbul's sole source of power between 1914 and 1952.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Silahtara%C4%9Fa_Power_Station" title="SilahtaraÄa Power Station">SilahtaraÄa Power Station</a>, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fossil-fuel_power_station" title="Fossil-fuel power station">coal-fired power plant</a> along the Golden Horn, was the sole source of Istanbul's electricity between 1914, when its first engine room was completed, and 1952.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-silah_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-silah-311">[303]</a></sup> Following the founding of the Turkish Republic, the plant underwent renovations to accommodate the city's increasing demand; its capacity grew from <span class="nowrap">23 megawatts</span> in 1923 to a peak of <span class="nowrap">120 megawatts</span> in 1956.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-silah_311-1"><a href="#cite_note-silah-311">[303]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-teias_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-teias-312">[304]</a></sup> Capacity declined until the power station reached the end of its economic life and shut down in 1983.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-silah_311-2"><a href="#cite_note-silah-311">[303]</a></sup> The state-run Turkish Electrical Authority (TEK) brieflyâbetween its founding in 1970 and 1984âheld a monopoly on the generation and distribution of electricity, but now the authorityâsince split between the Turkish Electricity Generation Transmission Company (TEAÅ) and the Turkish Electricity Distribution Company (TEDAÅ)âcompetes with private <a href="/wiki/Electric_utility" title="Electric utility">electric utilities</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-teias_312-1"><a href="#cite_note-teias-312">[304]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Ottoman Ministry of Post and Telegraph was established in 1840 and the first post office, the Imperial Post Office, opened near the courtyard of Yeni Mosque. By 1876, the first international mailing network between Istanbul and the lands beyond the Ottoman Empire had been established.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTT_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-PTT-313">[305]</a></sup> Sultan <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abd%C3%BClmecid_I" title="AbdÃ¼lmecid I">AbdÃ¼lmecid I</a> issued <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Morse" title="Samuel Morse">Samuel Morse</a> his first official honor for the <a href="/wiki/Electrical_telegraph" title="Electrical telegraph">telegraph</a> in 1847, and construction of the first telegraph lineâbetween Istanbul and <a href="/wiki/Edirne" title="Edirne">Edirne</a>âfinished in time to announce the end of the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_War" title="Crimean War">Crimean War</a> in 1856.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[306]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_Grand_Post_Office.jpg"><img alt="An arched neoclassical building with hanging PTT banners" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2268" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Istanbul_Grand_Post_Office.jpg/220px-Istanbul_Grand_Post_Office.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Istanbul_Grand_Post_Office.jpg/330px-Istanbul_Grand_Post_Office.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Istanbul_Grand_Post_Office.jpg/440px-Istanbul_Grand_Post_Office.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Istanbul_Grand_Post_Office.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_Main_Post_Office" title="Istanbul Main Post Office">Grand Post Office</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sirkeci" title="Sirkeci">Sirkeci</a>, Istanbul, was designed by <a href="/wiki/Vedat_Tek" title="Vedat Tek">Vedat Tek</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Turkey#1920s_to_early_1930s:_First_national_architectural_movement" title="Architecture of Turkey">Turkish neoclassical style</a> of the early 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[307]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>A nascent telephone system began to emerge in Istanbul in 1881 and after the first manual <a href="/wiki/Telephone_exchange" title="Telephone exchange">telephone exchange</a> became operational in Istanbul in 1909, the Ministry of Post and Telegraph became the Ministry of Post, Telegraph, and Telephone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTT_313-1"><a href="#cite_note-PTT-313">[305]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[308]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/GSM" title="GSM">GSM</a> cellular networks arrived in Turkey in 1994, with Istanbul among the first cities to receive the service.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkt_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-turkt-317">[309]</a></sup> Today, <a href="/wiki/Mobile_phone" title="Mobile phone">mobile</a> and <a href="/wiki/Landline" title="Landline">landline</a> service is provided by private companies, after <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCrk_Telekom" title="TÃ¼rk Telekom">TÃ¼rk Telekom</a>, which split from the Ministry of Post, Telegraph, and Telephone in 1995, was privatized in 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTT_313-2"><a href="#cite_note-PTT-313">[305]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-turkt_317-1"><a href="#cite_note-turkt-317">[309]</a></sup> Postal services remain under the purview of what is now the Post and Telegraph Organization (retaining the acronym PTT).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PTT_313-3"><a href="#cite_note-PTT-313">[305]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2000, Istanbul had <span class="nowrap">137 hospitals</span>, of which 100 were private.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[310]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title=" (August 2020)">needs update</span></a></i>]</sup> Turkish citizens are entitled to subsidized healthcare in the nation's state-run hospitals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-loc-pro_298-2"><a href="#cite_note-loc-pro-298">[290]</a></sup> As public hospitals tend to be overcrowded or otherwise slow, private hospitals are preferable for those who can afford them. Their prevalence has increased significantly over the last decade, as the percentage of outpatients using private hospitals increased from <span class="nowrap">6 percent</span> to <span class="nowrap">23 percent</span> between 2005 and 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-loc-pro_298-3"><a href="#cite_note-loc-pro-298">[290]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOxford_Business_Group2009197_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOxford_Business_Group2009197-319">[311]</a></sup> Many of these private hospitals, as well as some of the public hospitals, are equipped with high-tech equipment, including <a href="/wiki/Magnetic_resonance_imaging" title="Magnetic resonance imaging">MRI</a> machines, or associated with medical research centers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOxford_Business_Group2009198_320-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOxford_Business_Group2009198-320">[312]</a></sup> Turkey has more hospitals accredited by the U.S.-based <a href="/wiki/Joint_Commission" title="Joint Commission">Joint Commission</a> than any other country in the world, with most concentrated in its big cities. The high quality of healthcare, especially in private hospitals, has contributed to a recent upsurge in <a href="/wiki/Medical_tourism" title="Medical tourism">medical tourism</a> to Turkey (with a <span class="nowrap">40 percent</span> increase between 2007 and 2008).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[313]</a></sup> Laser <a href="/wiki/Eye_surgery" title="Eye surgery">eye surgery</a> is particularly common among medical tourists, as Turkey is known for specializing in the procedure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[314]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Public_transport_in_Istanbul" title="Public transport in Istanbul">Public transport in Istanbul</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:214px;max-width:214px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">The <a href="/wiki/Suspension_bridge" title="Suspension bridge">suspension bridges</a> on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bosphorus" title="Bosphorus">Bosphorus</a> strait</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:212px;max-width:212px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bosphorus_Bridge.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1161" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="119" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Bosphorus_Bridge.jpg/210px-Bosphorus_Bridge.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Bosphorus_Bridge.jpg/315px-Bosphorus_Bridge.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Bosphorus_Bridge.jpg/420px-Bosphorus_Bridge.jpg 2x" width="210"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Bosphorus_Bridge" title="Bosphorus Bridge">15 July Martyrs Bridge</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:212px;max-width:212px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fatih_sultan_mehmet_k%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1542" data-file-width="2960" decoding="async" height="109" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Fatih_sultan_mehmet_k%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_%28cropped%29.jpg/210px-Fatih_sultan_mehmet_k%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Fatih_sultan_mehmet_k%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_%28cropped%29.jpg/315px-Fatih_sultan_mehmet_k%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Fatih_sultan_mehmet_k%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_%28cropped%29.jpg/420px-Fatih_sultan_mehmet_k%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="210"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Fatih_Sultan_Mehmet_Bridge" title="Fatih Sultan Mehmet Bridge">Fatih Sultan Mehmet Bridge</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:212px;max-width:212px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Yavuz_sultan_selim_k%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2426" data-file-width="3479" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Yavuz_sultan_selim_k%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_%28cropped%29.jpg/210px-Yavuz_sultan_selim_k%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Yavuz_sultan_selim_k%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_%28cropped%29.jpg/315px-Yavuz_sultan_selim_k%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Yavuz_sultan_selim_k%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_%28cropped%29.jpg/420px-Yavuz_sultan_selim_k%C3%B6pr%C3%BCs%C3%BC_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="210"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Yavuz_Sultan_Selim_Bridge" title="Yavuz Sultan Selim Bridge">Yavuz Sultan Selim Bridge</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Istanbul's motorways network are the <a href="/wiki/Otoyol_1" title="Otoyol 1">O-1</a>, <a href="/wiki/Otoyol_2" title="Otoyol 2">O-2</a>, <a href="/wiki/Otoyol_3" title="Otoyol 3">O-3</a>, <a href="/wiki/Otoyol_4" title="Otoyol 4">O-4</a> and <a href="/wiki/Otoyol_7" title="Otoyol 7">O-7</a>.  The total length of Istanbul Province's <a href="/wiki/Toll_road" title="Toll road">toll motorways</a> network (<i>otoyollar</i>) is 543Â km (2021) and the state highways network (<i>devlet yollari</i>) is 353Â km (2021), totaling 896Â km of expressway roads (minimum 2x2 lanes), excluding secondary roads and urban streets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[315]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[316]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Otoyollar1_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-Otoyollar1-325">[317]</a></sup> The density of expressway network is 16.8Â km/100Â km<sup>2</sup>. The O-1 forms the city's inner <a href="/wiki/Ring_road" title="Ring road">ring road</a>, traversing the 15 July Martyrs (First Bosphorus) Bridge, and the O-2 is the city's outer ring road, crossing the Fatih Sultan Mehmet (Second Bosphorus) Bridge. The O-2 continues west to Edirne and the O-4 continues east to Ankara. The O-2, O-3, and O-4 are part of <a href="/wiki/European_route_E80" title="European route E80">European route E80</a> (the Trans-European Motorway) between Portugal and the <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Turkey_border" title="IranâTurkey border">IranâTurkey border</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-googma_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-googma-326">[318]</a></sup> In 2011, the first and second bridges on the Bosphorus carried <span class="nowrap">400,000 vehicles</span> each day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[319]</a></sup> The O-7<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[320]</a></sup> or Kuzey Marmara Otoyolu, is a motorway that bypass Istanbul to the north. The O-7 motorway from Kinali GiÅeleri to Istanbul Park Service has 139.2Â km, with 8 lanes (4x4), and from Odayeri-K10 to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_Atat%C3%BCrk_Airport" title="Istanbul AtatÃ¼rk Airport">Istanbul AtatÃ¼rk Airport</a> has 30.4Â km.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Otoyollar1_325-1"><a href="#cite_note-Otoyollar1-325">[317]</a></sup> The completed section of highway crosses the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bosphorus_Strait" title="Bosphorus Strait">Bosphorus Strait</a> via the <a href="/wiki/Yavuz_Sultan_Selim_Bridge" title="Yavuz Sultan Selim Bridge">Yavuz Sultan Selim (Third Bosphorus) Bridge</a>, entered service on 26 August 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[321]</a></sup> The O-7 motorway connects Istanbul AtatÃ¼rk Airport with Istanbul Airport. Environmentalist groups worry that the third bridge will endanger the remaining green areas to the north of Istanbul.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eib_330-0"><a href="#cite_note-eib-330">[322]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-let_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-let-331">[323]</a></sup> Apart from the three Bosphorus Bridges, the dual-deck, 14.6-kilometer (9.1Â mi) <a href="/wiki/Eurasia_Tunnel" title="Eurasia Tunnel">Eurasia Tunnel</a> (which entered service on 20 December 2016) under the Bosphorus strait also provides road crossings for motor vehicles between the Asian and European sides of Turkey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[324]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:164px;max-width:164px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:162px;max-width:162px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Nostalgic_tram_on_Istiklal_Avenue_in_Istanbul.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2585" data-file-width="3200" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Nostalgic_tram_on_Istiklal_Avenue_in_Istanbul.jpg/160px-Nostalgic_tram_on_Istiklal_Avenue_in_Istanbul.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Nostalgic_tram_on_Istiklal_Avenue_in_Istanbul.jpg/240px-Nostalgic_tram_on_Istiklal_Avenue_in_Istanbul.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/93/Nostalgic_tram_on_Istiklal_Avenue_in_Istanbul.jpg/320px-Nostalgic_tram_on_Istiklal_Avenue_in_Istanbul.jpg 2x" width="160"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:162px;max-width:162px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:T4_%C4%B0stanbul_Tram.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2604" data-file-width="4624" decoding="async" height="90" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/T4_%C4%B0stanbul_Tram.jpg/160px-T4_%C4%B0stanbul_Tram.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/T4_%C4%B0stanbul_Tram.jpg/240px-T4_%C4%B0stanbul_Tram.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/T4_%C4%B0stanbul_Tram.jpg/320px-T4_%C4%B0stanbul_Tram.jpg 2x" width="160"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Istanbul's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_nostalgic_tram" title="Istanbul nostalgic tram">nostalgic</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_modern_tram" title="Istanbul modern tram">modern tram</a> systems</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Istanbul's local public transportation system is a network of <a href="/wiki/Commuter_rail" title="Commuter rail">commuter trains</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tram" title="Tram">trams</a>, <a href="/wiki/Funicular" title="Funicular">funiculars</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metro_(rapid_transit)" title="Metro (rapid transit)">metro</a> lines, buses, <a href="/wiki/Bus_rapid_transit" title="Bus rapid transit">bus rapid transit</a>, and ferries. Fares across modes are integrated, using the <a href="/wiki/Contactless_smart_card" title="Contactless smart card">contactless</a> <a href="/wiki/Istanbulkart" title="Istanbulkart">Istanbulkart</a>, introduced in 2009, or the older <a href="/wiki/Akbil_(smart_ticket)" title="Akbil (smart ticket)">Akbil</a> electronic ticket device.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[325]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Trams_in_Istanbul" title="Trams in Istanbul">Trams in Istanbul</a> date back to 1872, when they were horse-drawn, but even the first electrified trams were decommissioned in the 1960s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iett-history_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-iett-history-334">[326]</a></sup> Operated by Istanbul Electricity, Tramway and Tunnels General Management (Ä°ETT), trams slowly returned to the city in the 1990s with the introduction of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_nostalgic_tram" title="Istanbul nostalgic tram">a nostalgic route</a> and a faster <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_modern_tram" title="Istanbul modern tram">modern tram line</a>, which now carries <span class="nowrap">265,000 passengers</span> each day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iett-history_334-1"><a href="#cite_note-iett-history-334">[326]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[327]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/T%C3%BCnel" title="TÃ¼nel">TÃ¼nel</a> opened in 1875 as the world's second-oldest subterranean rail line (after London's <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Railway" title="Metropolitan Railway">Metropolitan Railway</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iett-history_334-2"><a href="#cite_note-iett-history-334">[326]</a></sup> It still carries passengers between KarakÃ¶y and Ä°stiklal Avenue along a steep 573-meter (1,880Â ft) track; a more modern funicular between Taksim Square and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kabata%C5%9F,_Istanbul" title="KabataÅ, Istanbul">KabataÅ</a> began running in 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[328]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[329]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:164px;max-width:164px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:162px;max-width:162px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bogazici_Universitesi_metro.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2112" data-file-width="4608" decoding="async" height="73" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Bogazici_Universitesi_metro.jpg/160px-Bogazici_Universitesi_metro.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Bogazici_Universitesi_metro.jpg/240px-Bogazici_Universitesi_metro.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Bogazici_Universitesi_metro.jpg/320px-Bogazici_Universitesi_metro.jpg 2x" width="160"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Bo%C4%9Fazi%C3%A7i_University" title="BoÄaziÃ§i University">BoÄaziÃ§i University</a> station of the <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Metro" title="Istanbul Metro">Istanbul Metro</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:162px;max-width:162px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MarmarayAyr%C4%B1l%C4%B1k%C3%87e%C5%9FmesiStation.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="4928" decoding="async" height="106" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/MarmarayAyr%C4%B1l%C4%B1k%C3%87e%C5%9FmesiStation.JPG/160px-MarmarayAyr%C4%B1l%C4%B1k%C3%87e%C5%9FmesiStation.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/MarmarayAyr%C4%B1l%C4%B1k%C3%87e%C5%9FmesiStation.JPG/240px-MarmarayAyr%C4%B1l%C4%B1k%C3%87e%C5%9FmesiStation.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/MarmarayAyr%C4%B1l%C4%B1k%C3%87e%C5%9FmesiStation.JPG/320px-MarmarayAyr%C4%B1l%C4%B1k%C3%87e%C5%9FmesiStation.JPG 2x" width="160"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Marmaray" title="Marmaray">Marmaray commuter rail</a> at AyrÄ±lÄ±kÃ§eÅmesi station</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Metro" title="Istanbul Metro">Istanbul Metro</a> comprises eight lines (the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/M1_(Istanbul)" title="M1 (Istanbul)">M1</a>, <a href="/wiki/M2_(Istanbul_Metro)" title="M2 (Istanbul Metro)">M2</a>, <a href="/wiki/M3_(Istanbul_Metro)" title="M3 (Istanbul Metro)">M3</a>, <a href="/wiki/M6_(Istanbul_Metro)" title="M6 (Istanbul Metro)">M6</a>, <a href="/wiki/M7_(Istanbul_Metro)" title="M7 (Istanbul Metro)">M7</a> and <a href="/wiki/M9_(Istanbul_Metro)" title="M9 (Istanbul Metro)">M9</a> on the European side, and the <a href="/wiki/M4_(Istanbul_Metro)" title="M4 (Istanbul Metro)">M4</a> and <a href="/wiki/M5_(Istanbul_Metro)" title="M5 (Istanbul Metro)">M5</a> on the Asian side) with several other lines (<a href="/wiki/M8_(Istanbul_Metro)" title="M8 (Istanbul Metro)">M8</a>, <a href="/wiki/M12_(Istanbul_Metro)" title="M12 (Istanbul Metro)">M12</a> and <a href="/wiki/M11_(Istanbul_Metro)" title="M11 (Istanbul Metro)">M11</a>) and extensions under construction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[330]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[331]</a></sup> The two sides of Istanbul's metro are connected under the Bosphorus by the <a href="/wiki/Marmaray_Tunnel" title="Marmaray Tunnel">Marmaray Tunnel</a>, inaugurated in 2013 as the first rail connection between Thrace and Anatolia, having 13.5Â km length.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[332]</a></sup> The Marmaray tunnel together with the suburban railways lines along the Sea of Marmara, is part of intercontinental commuter rail line in Istanbul, from <a href="/wiki/Halkal%C4%B1_railway_station" title="HalkalÄ± railway station">HalkalÄ±</a> on the European side to <a href="/wiki/Gebze" title="Gebze">Gebze</a> on the Asian side. Marmaray rail line has 76.6Â km, and the full line opened on 12 March 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[333]</a></sup> Until then, buses provide transportation within and between the two-halves of the city, accommodating <span class="nowrap">2.2 million</span> passenger trips each day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[334]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Metrobus_(Istanbul)" title="Metrobus (Istanbul)">Metrobus</a>, a form of bus rapid transit, crosses the Bosphorus Bridge, with dedicated lanes leading to its termini.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[335]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/%C4%B0DO" title="Ä°DO">Ä°DO</a> (Istanbul Seabuses) runs a combination of all-passenger ferries and car-and-passenger ferries to ports on both sides of the Bosphorus, as far north as the Black Sea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[336]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[337]</a></sup> With additional destinations around the Sea of Marmara, Ä°DO runs the largest municipal ferry operation in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[338]</a></sup> The city's main cruise ship terminal is the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Istanbul" title="Port of Istanbul">Port of Istanbul</a> in KarakÃ¶y, with a capacity of 10,000 passengers per hour.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[339]</a></sup> Most visitors enter Istanbul by air, but about half a million foreign tourists enter the city by sea each year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iv&amp;c_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-iv&amp;c-348">[340]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary,_secondary_and_tertiary_sources" title="Wikipedia:No original research"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable secondary sources. (November 2020)">non-primary source needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bahnhofsfront-Istanbul-Sirkeci_retouched_2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="971" data-file-width="2398" decoding="async" height="89" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Bahnhofsfront-Istanbul-Sirkeci_retouched_2.jpg/220px-Bahnhofsfront-Istanbul-Sirkeci_retouched_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Bahnhofsfront-Istanbul-Sirkeci_retouched_2.jpg/330px-Bahnhofsfront-Istanbul-Sirkeci_retouched_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Bahnhofsfront-Istanbul-Sirkeci_retouched_2.jpg/440px-Bahnhofsfront-Istanbul-Sirkeci_retouched_2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bahnhofsfront-Istanbul-Sirkeci_retouched_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Originally opened in 1873 with a smaller terminal building as the main terminus of the <a href="/wiki/Chemins_de_fer_Orientaux" title="Chemins de fer Orientaux">Rumelia (Balkan) Railway</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>, which connected Istanbul with <a href="/wiki/Vienna" title="Vienna">Vienna</a>, the current <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%B0stanbul_Sirkeci_Terminal" title="Ä°stanbul Sirkeci Terminal">Sirkeci Terminal</a> building was constructed between 1888 and 1890, and became the eastern terminus of the <a href="/wiki/Orient_Express" title="Orient Express">Orient Express</a> from <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[341]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>International rail service from Istanbul launched in 1889, with a line between <a href="/wiki/Bucharest" title="Bucharest">Bucharest</a> and Istanbul's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Istanbul_Sirkeci_Terminal" title="Istanbul Sirkeci Terminal">Sirkeci Terminal</a>, which ultimately became famous as the eastern terminus of the <a href="/wiki/Orient_Express" title="Orient Express">Orient Express</a> from <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ha251_82-1"><a href="#cite_note-ha251-82">[76]</a></sup> Regular service to Bucharest and <a href="/wiki/Thessaloniki" title="Thessaloniki">Thessaloniki</a> continued until the early 2010s, when the former was interrupted for Marmaray construction but started running again in 2019 and the latter was halted due to economic problems in Greece.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[342]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[343]</a></sup> After Istanbul's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Haydarpa%C5%9Fa_Terminal" title="HaydarpaÅa Terminal">HaydarpaÅa Terminal</a> opened in 1908, it served as the western terminus of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baghdad_Railway" title="Baghdad Railway">Baghdad Railway</a> and an extension of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hejaz_Railway" title="Hejaz Railway">Hejaz Railway</a>; today, neither service is offered directly from Istanbul.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[344]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[345]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[346]</a></sup> Service to Ankara and other points across Turkey is normally offered by <a href="/wiki/Turkish_State_Railways" title="Turkish State Railways">Turkish State Railways</a>, but the construction of Marmaray and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ankara-Istanbul_high-speed_railway" title="Ankara-Istanbul high-speed railway">Ankara-Istanbul high-speed line</a> forced the station to close in 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-akay_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-akay-355">[347]</a></sup> New stations to replace both the HaydarpaÅa and Sirkeci terminals, and connect the city's disjointed railway networks, now the Marmaray second phase opened to the public.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-akay_355-1"><a href="#cite_note-akay-355">[347]</a></sup> Private bus companies still operation to this day. Istanbul's main bus station is the largest in Europe, with a daily capacity of <span class="nowrap">15,000 buses</span> and <span class="nowrap">600,000 passengers</span>, serving destinations as distant as <a href="/wiki/Frankfurt" title="Frankfurt">Frankfurt</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[348]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[349]</a></sup>
</p><p>Istanbul had three large international airports, two of which currently serve <a href="/wiki/Commercial_aviation" title="Commercial aviation">commercial passenger flights</a>. The largest is the new Istanbul Airport, opened in 2018 in the <a href="/wiki/Arnavutk%C3%B6y_(district)" title="ArnavutkÃ¶y (district)">ArnavutkÃ¶y</a> district to the northwest of the city center, on the European side, near the Black Sea coast.
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%C4%B0stanbul_Yeni_Havaliman%C4%B1_airport_Dec_2019.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1985" data-file-width="4787" decoding="async" height="91" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/%C4%B0stanbul_Yeni_Havaliman%C4%B1_airport_Dec_2019.jpg/220px-%C4%B0stanbul_Yeni_Havaliman%C4%B1_airport_Dec_2019.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/%C4%B0stanbul_Yeni_Havaliman%C4%B1_airport_Dec_2019.jpg/330px-%C4%B0stanbul_Yeni_Havaliman%C4%B1_airport_Dec_2019.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/%C4%B0stanbul_Yeni_Havaliman%C4%B1_airport_Dec_2019.jpg/440px-%C4%B0stanbul_Yeni_Havaliman%C4%B1_airport_Dec_2019.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Airport" title="Istanbul Airport">Istanbul Airport</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sabiha_G%C3%B6k%C3%A7en_Airport.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="1495" data-file-width="2159" decoding="async" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Sabiha_G%C3%B6k%C3%A7en_Airport.JPG/220px-Sabiha_G%C3%B6k%C3%A7en_Airport.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Sabiha_G%C3%B6k%C3%A7en_Airport.JPG/330px-Sabiha_G%C3%B6k%C3%A7en_Airport.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Sabiha_G%C3%B6k%C3%A7en_Airport.JPG/440px-Sabiha_G%C3%B6k%C3%A7en_Airport.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Sabiha_G%C3%B6k%C3%A7en_International_Airport" title="Istanbul Sabiha GÃ¶kÃ§en International Airport">Sabiha GÃ¶kÃ§en Airport</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>All scheduled commercial passenger flights were transferred from Istanbul AtatÃ¼rk Airport to Istanbul Airport on 6 April 2019, following the closure of Istanbul AtatÃ¼rk Airport for scheduled passenger flights.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[350]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IATA_code" title="IATA code">IATA airport code</a> IST was also transferred to the new airport.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[351]</a></sup> Once all phases are completed in 2025, the airport will have six sets of runways (eight in total), 16 taxiways, and will be able to accommodate 200Â million passengers a year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[352]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[353]</a></sup> The transfer from the airport to the city is via the O-7, and it will eventually be linked by two lines of the Istanbul Metro.
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sabiha_G%C3%B6k%C3%A7en_International_Airport" title="Sabiha GÃ¶kÃ§en International Airport">Sabiha GÃ¶kÃ§en International</a>, 45 kilometers (28Â mi) southeast of the city center, on the Asian side, was opened in 2001 to relieve AtatÃ¼rk. Dominated by <a href="/wiki/Low-cost_carrier" title="Low-cost carrier">low-cost carriers</a>, Istanbul's second airport has rapidly become popular, especially since the opening of a new international terminal in 2009;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[354]</a></sup> the airport handled <span class="nowrap">14.7 million</span> passengers in 2012, a year after <a href="/wiki/Airports_Council_International" title="Airports Council International">Airports Council International</a> named it the world's fastest-growing airport.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[355]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[356]</a></sup> AtatÃ¼rk had also experienced rapid growth, as its <span class="nowrap">20.6 percent</span> rise in passenger traffic between 2011 and 2012 was the highest among the world's top 30 airports.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aci_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-aci-365">[357]</a></sup>
</p><p>Istanbul AtatÃ¼rk Airport, located 24 kilometers (15Â mi) west of the city center, on the European side, near the Marmara Sea coast, was formerly the city's largest airport. After its closure to commercial flights in 2019, it was briefly used by cargo aircraft and the official state aircraft owned by the Turkish government, until the demolition of its runway began in 2020. It handled <span class="nowrap">61.3 million</span> passengers in 2015, which made it the <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_Europe" title="List of the busiest airports in Europe">third-busiest airport in Europe</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airports_by_passenger_traffic" title="World's busiest airports by passenger traffic">18th-busiest in the world</a> in that year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aci_365-1"><a href="#cite_note-aci-365">[357]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">Environment</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Flora_and_fauna">Flora and fauna</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Atat%C3%BCrkArboretum_(17).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="4928" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Atat%C3%BCrkArboretum_%2817%29.jpg/220px-Atat%C3%BCrkArboretum_%2817%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Atat%C3%BCrkArboretum_%2817%29.jpg/330px-Atat%C3%BCrkArboretum_%2817%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Atat%C3%BCrkArboretum_%2817%29.jpg/440px-Atat%C3%BCrkArboretum_%2817%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Atat%C3%BCrkArboretum_(17).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk_Arboretum" title="AtatÃ¼rk Arboretum">AtatÃ¼rk Arboretum</a> is an <a href="/wiki/Arboretum" title="Arboretum">arboretum</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/City_forest" title="City forest">city forest</a> located in <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A7ek%C3%B6y,_Sar%C4%B1yer" title="BahÃ§ekÃ¶y, SarÄ±yer">BahÃ§ekÃ¶y</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sar%C4%B1yer" title="SarÄ±yer">SarÄ±yer</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The natural vegetation cover of the Bosporus region is made up of <a href="/wiki/Temperate_broadleaf_and_mixed_forests" title="Temperate broadleaf and mixed forests">temperate broadleaf and mixed forests</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_forests,_woodlands,_and_scrub" title="Mediterranean forests, woodlands, and scrub">pseudo-maquis</a>'. <a href="/wiki/Chestnut" title="Chestnut">Chestnut</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oak" title="Oak">oak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elm" title="Elm">elm</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tilia" title="Tilia">linden</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fraxinus" title="Fraxinus">ash</a> and <a href="/wiki/Robinia" title="Robinia">locust</a> comprises the most prominent  tree genera. The most important species belonging to maquis formation are <a href="/wiki/Laurus_nobilis" title="Laurus nobilis">laurel</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Terebinth" title="Terebinth">terebinth</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Cercis_siliquastrum" title="Cercis siliquastrum">Cercis siliquastrum</a></i>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spartium_junceum" title="Spartium junceum">broom</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pyracantha_coccinea" title="Pyracantha coccinea">red firethorn</a>, and oak species such as <i><a href="/wiki/Quercus_cerris" title="Quercus cerris">Quercus cerris</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Quercus_coccifera" title="Quercus coccifera">Quercus coccifera</a></i>. Apart from the natural flora <a href="/wiki/Platanus_orientalis" title="Platanus orientalis"><i>Platanus orentalis</i></a>, <a href="/wiki/Aesculus_hippocastanum" title="Aesculus hippocastanum">horse chestnut</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cupressus_sempervirens" title="Cupressus sempervirens">cypress</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stone_pine" title="Stone pine">stone pine</a> make up the <a href="/wiki/Introduced_species" title="Introduced species">introduced species</a> that got <a href="/wiki/Acclimatization" title="Acclimatization">acclimatized</a> to Istanbul.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[358]</a></sup> In a study that examined urban flora in <a href="/wiki/Kartal" title="Kartal">Kartal</a>, a total of 576 plant taxa were recorded; of those 477 were natural and 99 were exotic and cultivated. The most native taxa were in the <a href="/wiki/Asteraceae" title="Asteraceae">Asteraceae</a> family (50 species), while the most diverse exotic plant family was <a href="/wiki/Rosaceae" title="Rosaceae">Rosaceae</a> (16 species).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[359]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Turkish_Straits" title="Turkish Straits">Turkish Straits</a> and Sea of Marmara play a vital role for <a href="/wiki/Fish_migration" title="Fish migration">migrating fish</a> and other marine animals between Mediterranean, Marmara and Black Sea. Bosporus hosts <a href="/wiki/Pelagic_fish" title="Pelagic fish">pelagic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Demersal_fish" title="Demersal fish">demersal</a> and semipelagic fish species and more than 130 different taxa have been documented in the strait.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[360]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bluefish" title="Bluefish">Bluefish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bonito" title="Bonito">bonito</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sea_bass" title="Sea bass">sea bass</a>, <a href="/wiki/Horse_mackerel" title="Horse mackerel">horse mackerel</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_anchovy" title="European anchovy">anchovies</a> composes the economically important species. Fish diversity in the waters of Istanbul has dwindled in the recent decades. From around 60 different fish species recorded in the 1970s only 20 of them still survive in the Bosporus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[361]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute#Disputed_statement" title="Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute"><span title="The material near this tag is possibly inaccurate or nonfactual. (July 2021)">dubious</span></a> <span class="metadata"> â <a href="/wiki/Talk:Istanbul#Dubious" title="Talk:Istanbul">discuss</a></span></i>]</sup><a href="/wiki/Common_bottlenose_dolphin" title="Common bottlenose dolphin">Common bottlenose dolphin</a> (Turkish: <i>afalina</i>), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Short-beaked_common_dolphin" title="Short-beaked common dolphin">short-beaked common dolphin</a> (Turkish: <i>tÄ±rtak</i>) and <a href="/wiki/Harbour_porpoise" title="Harbour porpoise">harbor porpoise</a> (Turkish: <i>mutur</i>) make up the marine mammals presently found in the Bosporus and surrounding waters, though since the 1950s the number of dolphin observations has become increasingly rare. <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_monk_seal" title="Mediterranean monk seal">Mediterranean monk seals</a> were present in Bosporus, and Princes' Islands and Tuzla shores were seal breeding areas during summer, but they have not been observed in Istanbul since the 1960s and thought to be extinct in the region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[362]</a></sup> Water pollution, <a href="/wiki/Overfishing" title="Overfishing">overfishing</a> and destruction of coastal habitats caused by urbanization are main threats to Istanbul's marine ecology.  
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:S%C3%BCleymaniye_Camii_Haziresi%27nde_bir_kedi.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/S%C3%BCleymaniye_Camii_Haziresi%27nde_bir_kedi.jpg/220px-S%C3%BCleymaniye_Camii_Haziresi%27nde_bir_kedi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/S%C3%BCleymaniye_Camii_Haziresi%27nde_bir_kedi.jpg/330px-S%C3%BCleymaniye_Camii_Haziresi%27nde_bir_kedi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/S%C3%BCleymaniye_Camii_Haziresi%27nde_bir_kedi.jpg/440px-S%C3%BCleymaniye_Camii_Haziresi%27nde_bir_kedi.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:S%C3%BCleymaniye_Camii_Haziresi%27nde_bir_kedi.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Street cats in the city</div></div></div>
<p>Wild land mammals are mainly concentrated in the northern forested areas of Istanbul. <a href="/wiki/Roe_deer" title="Roe deer">Roe deer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wild_boar" title="Wild boar">wild boars</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fox" title="Fox">foxes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coyote" title="Coyote">coyotes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marten" title="Marten">martens</a>, <a href="/wiki/Badger" title="Badger">badgers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wolf" title="Wolf">wolves</a>, <a href="/wiki/Weasel" title="Weasel">weasels</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wildcat" title="Wildcat">wildcats</a>, <a href="/wiki/Squirrel" title="Squirrel">squirrels</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jungle_cat" title="Jungle cat">reed cats</a> have been documented to live inside the boundaries of Istanbul Province.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[363]</a></sup> Apart from the wild land mammals Istanbul hosts a sizeable <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stray_animal" title="Stray animal">stray animal</a> population. The presence of <a href="/wiki/Feral_cats_in_Istanbul" title="Feral cats in Istanbul">feral cats in Istanbul</a>  (<a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">Turkish</a>: <i>sokak kedisi</i>) is noted to be very prevalent, with estimates ranging from a hundred thousand to over a million stray cats. The feral cats in the city have gained widespread media and public attention and are considered to be symbols of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[364]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[365]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rose-ringed_parakeet" title="Rose-ringed parakeet">Rose-ringed parakeet</a> colonies are present in urban areas, similar to other European cities as <a href="/wiki/Feral_parrot" title="Feral parrot">feral parrots</a>, and considered as <a href="/wiki/Invasive_species" title="Invasive species">invasive species</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[366]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pollution">Pollution</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Air_pollution_in_Turkey" title="Air pollution in Turkey">Air pollution in Turkey</a> is acute in Ä°stanbul with cars, buses and taxis causing frequent urban <a href="/wiki/Smog" title="Smog">smog</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[367]</a></sup> as it is one of the few European cities without a <a href="/wiki/Low-emission_zone" title="Low-emission zone">low-emission zone</a>. As of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Istanbul&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> the city's mean <a href="/wiki/Air_quality_index" title="Air quality index">air quality</a> remains of a level so as to affect the heart and lungs of healthy street bystanders during peak traffic hours,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[368]</a></sup> and almost 200 days of pollution were measured by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Air_pollution_sensor" title="Air pollution sensor">air pollution sensors</a> at <a href="/wiki/Sultangazi" title="Sultangazi">Sultangazi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mecidiyek%C3%B6y" title="MecidiyekÃ¶y">MecidiyekÃ¶y</a>, AlibeykÃ¶y and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ka%C4%9F%C4%B1thane" title="KaÄÄ±thane">KaÄÄ±thane</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[369]</a></sup> It is one of the 10 worst cities for NO2.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[370]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Algal_bloom" title="Algal bloom">Algal blooms</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Red_tide" title="Red tide">red tides</a> were reported in Sea of Marmara and Bosporus (especially in Golden Horn), and regularly happen in urban lakes such as <a href="/wiki/Lake_B%C3%BCy%C3%BCk%C3%A7ekmece" title="Lake BÃ¼yÃ¼kÃ§ekmece">Lake BÃ¼yÃ¼kÃ§ekmece</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lake_K%C3%BC%C3%A7%C3%BCk%C3%A7ekmece" title="Lake KÃ¼Ã§Ã¼kÃ§ekmece">KÃ¼Ã§Ã¼kÃ§ekmece</a>. In June 2021 a <a href="/wiki/Marine_mucilage" title="Marine mucilage">marine mucilage</a> wave allegedly caused by water pollution spread to Sea of Marmara.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[371]</a></sup>
</p>
